country:

text:
I didn't give it 5 stars 'cause I made changes based on others' suggestions that I felt improved the recipe.  I halved the peppers (lengthwise), sauted onions separately along with 2 minced garlic pieces, cooked the rice separately, used 1 can of DICED tomatoes* (why would you ever buy a can of tomatoes and THEN dice them?), and mixed the ingredients together after browning the beef**, allowing them to warm slightly in the skillet before stuffing into the peppers.  You can use the extra juice from the can of tomatoes to keep the rice from burning.  I also added quite a bit of basil, oregano, and Italian seasoning, as well as extra Worcestershire sauce.  Putting just a little cheese in the bottom of each pepper helped as well.  Lastly, I only used one can of tomato soup.  Even cut in half, 25 min was needed to get them nice & hot.  Next time, I'll try adding some pepper as well.
* Using a can of diced tomatoes with jalepeno peppers adds just the right amount of kick to these!  **You can also use 1/2 beef & 1/2 3-7% lean ground turkey to reduce fat content...tastes the same!

text:
great recipe. I cut the amount of rice in half. Only thing I would change is at the end. Fill in the peppers halfway with the beef mixture. Add a bit of tomato sauce and fill up the rest with beef mixture and top with tomato sauce again. The problem with only topping off the tomato sauce at the end was that it did not "seep" down as I expected it. So the top only had the tomato sauce and the bottom did not. Without the tomato sauce, the beef was kind of bland.

text:
Wonderful! My whole family enjoyed these.  I'll definitely make this again.  I used ground turkey instead of beef, and a can of petite diced tomatoes w/ liquid instead of whole toms.  Used Arborio rice as that's what I had in the pantry.  Added minced garlic to the meat mixture. I substituted 1/2 C. of beef broth instead of plain water. Used 1 can of tomato soup & 1 sm. can of tomato sauce w/ a TBS or two of Spaghetti Sauce Seasoning.  Excellent, healthy, and much better than the stuffed peppers I had as a child.  I think that par-boiling the peppers before stuffing them was key to the texture and flavor.

I have made these several times and they have been perfect everytime with some little adjustments.  I double the worcestershire sauce, add garlic with the onions, put the cheese on top of the stuffed peppers, and use tomato paste instead of soup with about a tablespoon of lemon juice.  Fabulous comfort food and very healthy!  Note: I have also used both ground chicken and turkey and also had great results.

I used onion powder instead of onion, tomato sauce instead of tomato soup and beef broth instead of water for the rice. I also added another half cup of cheese, but I don't think a little more would hurt. They taste even better the second day.

text:
Yum yum!  I've never made stuffed peppers before.  These were great!  I used ground turkey instead of beef b/c we're trying to eat healthier.  Used Uncle Ben's converted Rice, in my opinion it is the best rice in a box.  Used a large can of diced tomatoes, undrained.  Did not even use tomato soup, I don't think you need to.  After stuffing my peppers with the mixture, I just placed them right side up in a greased 9x13.  Biggest tip - boil your peppers for a good 5 minutes in the beginning, before stuffing them, and make sure they are fully submerged beneath the water.  If not, you will likely end up with pretty raw, crunchy peppers even after baking, unless you like to eat them that way.  One of my peppers was like this, it was the one that never got submerged when boiling. The main thing I love about this recipe -  you get your meat, starch, and green veggie all in one shot, and it is delicious and healthy!  Thank you.

city:

country:
None
text:
This is a decent but very basic recipe.  Here are my thoughts.  First of all, don't cut the top off the pepper, it wastes too much pepper, cut it in half lengthwise.  The beef and rice stuffing is rather bland.  Easily liven it up by doubling (or more) the Worcestershire.  Fresh garlic adds to it as well.  Also, as others have already noted, adding some dried basil and/or oregano to the stuffing works well too.  And why in the world would you buy a can of whole tomatoes and then chop them?  Just use a can of diced tomatoes!  Don't use soup as the topping.  Use your favorite pasta sauce.  But if you do use the tomato soup, don't add water, it will just dilute what little flavor there is.  Simply pour the soup into a bowl, heat it a bit in the microwave and stir.  Viola, there's the gravy consistency the recipe calls for and no water needed.  After stuffing the pepper, ladle on the pasta sauce and then using a 2nd cup of cheese top each pepper.  You can then top the cheese with a sprinkle of dried oregano or Italian seasoning.  Happy eating!

I thought these were good but I have had better. Per previous reviews, I too added a bay leaf, a beef bullion cube and a tsp of oregano when cooking the rice. I also used sharp cheddar cheese.  Although there is rice in the peppers, we served over additional white rice so we could spoon the sauce over all.  Although we liked the meal, I feel it needs a little more "umph" to top it off.  It has great potential and I will probally make again only I'll play around with it to find the right blend to fully satisfy our tastebuds.

text:
The sausage was a nice change from the usual ground beef or turkey. I didn't par cook the peppers and top of stove cook time was much less than an hour. Otherwise the recipe was a breeze. I didn't see anyone else mention this in the reviews, but 3 cups of rice would have been ridiculously way too much. I didn't even use two full cups of uncooked rice and it was plenty for the six peppers. I also didn't use instant rice, so maybe that's what made the difference.

text:
This is really close to my granmothers recipe but a whole lot more work! I don't pre-cook anything! Follow the instructions for prepping the peppers, combine  the stuffing ingredients and lightly stuff the peppers, place in a dutch oven filled with soup/water combination, cover and simmer until peppers are soft and stuffing is cooked through.  A lot less work and you're not lighting the oven! I usually make some extra meatballs out of the stuffing mix for those of us who don't like peppers.  Served with mashed potatoes and the gravy from the peppers alongside cucumber salad and sweetcorn you've got a great meal!

This recipe is pretty much the way I cook my stuffed peppers.  But instead of putting the green peppers in boiling water, I found it was much easier to clean the green peppers, half them and put cut side down staggered on a glass plate and then microwaving them for 3 - 4 minutes on high.  Then fill and bake!  They turn out perfectly!

text:
I gave this recipe 5 stars because it is a great base recipe that can be customized pretty easily. I followed the advice of other reviewers and made the following changes. I sauteed some minced garlic with the ground beef and onion. I also had some bell pepper left over that I needed to use, so I chopped that up and sauteed that with the mixture as well. I used a can of diced tomatoes with green chiles (undrained) in place of the whole peeled tomatoes and doubled the Worcestershire. I used beef broth in place of the 1/2 cup of water and some Italian seasoning and some cayenne pepper for extra seasoning. For the cheese, I had a Cheddar Jack blend and made sure to sprinkle some on top during the last 5 minutes of baking. It was very tasty! The rice wasn't quite done after simmering in the beef mixture for 15 minutes, so next time I will cook the rice separately and add it at the end. Next time I'm also going to try wild rice for a little extra flavor.

text:
My boyfriend and I just LOVE this stuffed bell pepper recipe... we did follow a few of the suggestions made by other reviewers and I think it adds up to the perfect dish:
*Slice the peppers length wise and remove the seeds, and after boiling, sprinkle a little cheese inside each half
*Double, or even triple the worcestershire
*Use a can of diced tomatoes with the seasoning already added (we chose garlic and basil)
*Cook the rice in beef or chicken broth in a separate pan, this helps ensure that the rice is tender and flavorful.. then add it to the beef and simmer for 5-10 mins so it all blends together
*Add garlic to the beef and onions while cooking
*Dont add water to the tomato soup, and make sure you sprinkle cheese on top of the peppers before baking! :) Delish!

text:
OH my goodness.  Everyone should ALWAYS cook rice before adding it to beef stuffings! Cabbage rolls, cook the rice first, stuffed peppers, cook the rice first.  Always look at your ingredients first.  If there is a ingredient that takes longer to cook than the main ing. cook it first, cool it before adding it to the main ing. so you dont start the cooking process before you pop it in the oven.  Rate 4 stars

text:
Super easy and so tasty!  I made it for two, but don't trust the measurements when you change the servings.  I made it with 2 green peppers, split in halves.  Sauteed onions & celery and added some garlic powder.  Used 1 pound of ground beef, 1 cup of rice and 1 can of rotel chopped tomatoes. I added 1 cup of water and a dash of worcestershire sauce.  Mix in the cheese then stuff the green peppers.  I heaped the mixture on to each bell pepper where it was overflowing but still in the pepper.  Covered with tomato soup and water mixture, cheese and panko breadcrumbs for 30 mins.  Oh sooooo good!  It makes a lot of "stuffing" but its perfect!

Instead of stuffing the peppers then pouring everything on top. I layer it. Cheese, meat, sauce. Until I get to the top. That way it's not dry. And of course I put a lot of cheese on top. My family and our friends LOVE them!

Display Name:
Shannon

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
After 3-4 times preparing this recipe, I always use this one as a base, taking quite a few liberties, due to time constraints and family preferences. I parboil the peppers for 10 minutes. After slicing the tops off the peppers, I chop the remnants and sautee them along with my onions. I then brown 93/7 hamburger meat with our family's favorite spices (I also add considerably more than 1 tsp of worchestershire too!). I throw in a mixture of 1/2 cheddar and 1/2 mozzarella (or Italian blend or whatever else I have on hand) and mix that right into the warm meat mixture. I also cheat and use the 90-second Uncle Ben's Wild Rice pouch and mix that right into the hamburger/cheese mixture as well. I like a bit more structure and flavor to my sauce, so I use the Tomato Cream Sauce for Pasta, found on this site too. I then add a couple ladles of the sauce to the hamburger and blend well. It makes the hamburger/rice mixture just the perfect consistency to spoon into the peppers.  Then, I pour the remaining sauce over the assembled peppers, add more cheese to the pepper tops and bake for 20 minutes (parboiling the peppers a bit longer will shorten your baking time). Easy peasy...not to mention wonderfully delicious! This is a great recipe to add your flair to since you can sub out different colored peppers, use ground turkey instead of hamburger meat, play around with sauces, etc. Thanks for the submission....I'll use this recipe as my base over and over again.

text:
I also use tomato paste rather than tomatoes, also tomato soup is too sweet so I use tomato juice if needed. We don't like green peppers so I use red, orange or yellow, they're sweeter and not so "bitey". After stuffing the peppers, my mom always just put them in the skillet, topped them with more cheese, the tomato juice and cooked them covered till heated through.  No baking required. She also added basil, parsley and garlic to the beef mixture. She made these for over 65 years, and her mother before her so she had time to perfect the recipe.

text:
I gave this 4 stars instead of 5 only because the tips from other reviewers seemed to improve the recipe drastically. Bottom line: The peppers were excellent!  From others' suggestions, I added two cloves of garlic (chopped); added lots of Italian seasoning, plus more basil and oregano; used diced, canned tomatoes flavored with basil and oregano; doubled the Worchestershire; substituted spaghetti sauce for tomato soup; doubled the rice and cooked it ahead of time; used some red peppers as well as green ones; and used at least 1.5 cups of grated cheddar. The 60-minute time frame is conservative, especially if you make it the way I did. Cooking the rice alone took 20 minutes; I had to cook two batches of peppers; browning the beef took about 15 minutes; and the peppers cooked in the oven at least 35 minutes.  All in all, a great basic recipe, easily adapted to what you have on hand and what your family prefers. I'll definitely make these again.

text:
I made my stuffed peppers like this when I first started cooking but now that I've gotten back to eating healthier, I've lightened it up a bit. We don't like green bell peppers so I use red, orange or yellow. I now use ground turkey, fire-roasted tomatoes, brown rice that I've cooked before hand and I omit the water. I also use organic tomato sauce and throw in a mess of minced fresh garlic. This totally bends well to what I have on hand and if I want to make it stretch with half the meat, I sub in shredded or chopped veggies (we favor zucchini, carrots, spinach or broccoli) and sometimes I'll spice it up with a teaspoon or two of homemade italian seasoning or taco seasoning. Whatever I grab first. This is always a filling meal that my family always inhales. If you've got the time and patience, this is also a good recipe to double and freeze one container for another time.

text:
I never grew up on stuffed peppers, so I like to try a variety of recipes since I don't know what "right" tastes like. I think I may have finally figured it out tonight. I kept the amounts the same, just swapped out some smoked provola and scamorza for the cheddar, since I like to use as much local ingredients as possible. For anyone who can get their hands on real Italian cheese, a 50/50 blend of smoked provola and scamorza is absolutely amazing in these peppers. I was hesitant on using a can of tomato soup as a gravy, but it really did add that extra touch that I feel stuffed peppers need. I'll still try new recipes out, but this is certainly our families default from here on out.

text:
I didn't read other reviews before making this.  A few comments on the recipe:  1.  There is no human way rice could ever go from uncooked to tender in 15 minutes.  Cook it ahead.  2.  I printed a shopping list w/o reading the recipe, and it doesn't make sense to buy whole tomatoes only to chop them.  I'd use pre-diced.  So.  Aside from the rice being crunchy (after adding 10 minutes of simmer time) and there not being enough filling for the sixth pepper, the overall flavor of these was good.  I felt it needed more rice and maybe some other ingredients to bring it to a five star level.  Thanks though.

city:

country:
None
text:
I modified this recipe a bit based on what was cheaper and what I had on hand... 

First I used 4 green peppers and lean ground turkey meat. I cooked the onion first, then I cooked the turkey with it, seasoned with s&p and a little oregano. 

I had a packet of that 90 second rice, long grain brown from good old uncle ben, so I added that. I never added worcestershire sauce, and I substituted the tomato soup for two 8 oz cans of plain old tomato sauce. I mixed everything together (minus about 1/3 c tomato sauce) in a bowl and added about 3 tbsp of good quality parm cheese. I spooned the rest of the tomato sauce into the bottoms of the peppers, then filled them to the top with the mixture. I covered the baking pan tightly with foil and baked on 350 for 45 minutes. With 10 minutes left I uncovered them and threw a ton of cheddar cheese on top. I also find it tastes amazing with cholula hot sauce.

text:
wow, i'd give this 6 stars if i could.  i made these because my boyfriend likes stuffed peppers, but we both loved them!!  i made a few modifications.  instead of the tomato soup and whole peeled tomatoes, i just added 2 tablespoons of garlic, 3 teaspoons of italian seasoning, two 8oz cans of tomato sauce, and one 14.5oz can of diced tomatoes (with garlic, basil, and oregano) into the simmering meat mixture.  i also used lean ground beef and a parmesan/mozerella cheese mix vs. the cheddar.  its really good if you put the extra stuffing mix in the baking dish around the peppers. in the last 10 minutes of cooking, i topped each pepper with mozerella and parmesan cheeses and broiled until browned.  so yummy!!

I didn't like stuffed peppers as a child, but I sure do now!  I loved this recipe!!!  The only thing that I did differently was add a small can of drained sweet corn (frozen would work also).  I really like the tomato sauce that the peppers cook in, and have not found many recipes like this one (i.e. peppers topped with tomato sauce). text:
This is the first time I have ever made stuffed Green Peppers.  My whole family, including my son's 11 year old friend & my 13 year old daughter, loved these!!  I did use others ideas.  I did 3/4 cup rice & water & I added all seasonings you would put in spaghetti sauce, like Italian, Parsley, Basil, garlic salt, Oregano & of course 3 fresh garlic cloves.  I also used only 1 can of the soup, as I do not like too much tomato flavor.  I also put the meat mixture in 1/2 way, then the soup, then more meat & more soup & did not top it with more cheese.  It didn't need more & I do count calories.  This was a really nice, filling dish!!

text:
I read some of the other reviews and here's what I did ....  I added garlic and onion powder, a little bit of oregano, 1/2 tsp more of the Worcestershire sauce, and a small squirt of Red Hot sauce .... I put a little bit of cheese in the bottom of the peppers before I filled them .... I filled the peppers half full and put a little of the tomato soup mix in .... I did NOT mix ANY of the cheese in with the mixture .... I finished filling the peppers, put in more tomato soup, and THEN I topped it all with the cheese .... when I used the tomato soup, I added about 1/2 can of water, OH .... and I also used a can of diced tomatoes like other reviewers said .... AND I had about 1 cup of leftover corn (frozen not canned) and added that .... they came out fantastic .... do NOT be afraid to season because they would have been incredibly bland had I not put seasoning in ...

text:
Sauteed my onion and fresh minced garlic in extra virgin olive oil.  Added, ground turkey meat, basil, oregano, and cilantro.  I used red bell peppers rather than green as the red has a slightly sweeter taste to me.  Placed some shredded white extra sharp cheddar cheese in the bottom of the peppers, filled half the pepper with the meat mixture, then a spoon full of condensed tomato soup, then finished filling the peppers and topped with another spoon full of tomato soup.  Baked at 375 degrees F for 45 minutes.  Placed some more shredded extra sharp cheddar cheese on top of the peppers for the last five minutes of baking.  Whoooo, Buuuuddy!  It was delicious!  Served with steamed broccoli and cauliflower with a side of black olives.  It garnered me another Stamp of Approval (SOA) award from Mi Gato Loco.

LOve this recipe but I as always read reviews. I made changes to mine and my husbands liking. I have made this recipe twice, the first time I used half pound hamburger and half pound sausage. instead of water I used beef broth. I used mozzrella chees since it melts better and I used Rotell. I looked at alot of photos that others had shared and I was alittle grossed out that the pepper and filling was floating in Tomato soup (I used Tomato sauce). I only used about a 1/4 cup of tomato sauce to line the bottom of the pan and a few little drips of sauce in each pepper and added mozzerella cheese on top. Very wonderful recipe but eveb better with the changes I made. The second time I made it. it was requested and I did not have Hamburger so I used only sausage and it had lots more flavor.

text:
I have always loved stuffed bell peppers, and when I was given a large box of produce I jumped at the chance to make them (much to the distain of my poor hubby, lol). I did make my own changes (I did not read the other's reviews beforehand, but noticed a lot of similarities). First off, I never have canned tomato soup on hand. So instead I used 2 8oz cans of tomato sauce. I poured it into a bowl and added a generous amount of garlic powder, salt, pepper, onion powder, basil, and Italian seasoning. I mixed it well and it tasted delicious as my "tomato soup". Then, instead of the canned chopped tomatoes (I had none on hand), I added 2 8oz canned to the browning ground beef. So in my pot was browning ground beef and onions, salt, pepper, onion powder, garlic powder, rice, and maybe 3 tablespoons of worcestershire sauce. I did not have any chedder cheese, so I shredded a block of mozzarella cheese instead-which turned out great! After I baked everything in the oven, it was DELICIOUS! My husband was even shocked that his childhood dinner nightmare was so tasty. I say that this recipe is well worth the 5 stars. :) I always add extra seasonings to everything.

this was very good and very easy to make.  the only thing that i will change is the texture of the meat stuffing.  i am used to adding egg and breadcrumbs with rice.  the only thing really holding together the stuffing was the cheese added.  i will use this recipe again, but i will make the stuffing the traditional way.

angelgirl

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674164.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I suppose the recipe by itself isn't 4 stars, but its a good base to customize to your families taste. I added a lot of different seasonings. I precooked the rice in chicken broth in my rice cooker. If you keep the rice slightly on the dry side, it will still absorb more moisture when baking w/o getting soggy. I sauteed the meat by itself. While it was draining I sauteed the onion (used double what was called for) with some minced garlic and then added the meat back in. I used a whole can of diced tomotoes(and juice) and half a 15 oz can tomato sauce. The rest of the seasonings I added a little at a time until it tasted right: garlic seasoned salt, garlic, white pepper, black pepper, 1 cube beef bullion, cumin, oregano, thyme, worchestshire sauce, louisiana hot sauce, lots of mild cheddar, I think that's all. I just kept adding until I like it. I washed and salted the peppers, but did not par boil them. I prefer them to be less done and have more structure. They were topped with sliced mild cheddar. I used half the meat mixture and froze the rest. I will update when I use the next half, but I expect it will be just fine, not much different than freezing meatloaf mix which I do all the time.

text:
This was my first time trying stuffed bell peppers ever and they were so delicious. I can't imagine that there could be a better recipe to use. So yummy! We've added this to our dinner rotation. We use ground turkey. We also use a can of diced tomatoes instead of whole peeled tomatoes. And we only use about one can of tomato soup, not diluted. For the tomato soup, we fill the peppers about halfway with the meat mixtre, then add 1-2 spoonfulls of tomato soup in each pepper, then fill the rest of the way with the meat mixture. Top with sauce, then more shredded cheddar cheese. We also only make 4 peppers. This recipe fills 4 peppers up to the top with just the right amount of mixture.

text:
This is a great recipe!  However, I changed the following based on previous reviews:  used 2 cans rotel original drained instead of whole peeled tomatoes, used 1/4 cup Worcestershire sauce, 1 1/2 cups cooked rice, 2 cups fat free cheedar cheese and 1/2 cup fat free mozarella for topping, and added fresh garlic and cumin to the ground beef.  I also used 96/4 lean ground beef.  Made this dish very healty and tasty. If going by Weight Watchers this comes to only 6 points per pepper!

text:
It was a bit bland. Next time I will double the worchestershire sauce and add garlic, as others have suggested. Also, I often assemble stuffed peppers ahead of time and freeze them until needed. I simply place the filled peppers on a cookie sheet in the freezer until they're completely solid, then wrap them individually and seal them in a freezer bag. To bake, I remove the needed peppers, unwrap and thaw them on a paper towel, then transfer them to a baking dish and bake for 25-30 minutes.

I tried this recipe because I'm always into trying something new. First off, I used 2 large green peppers and the recommended meat and rice measurements worked just fine. I opted to use ground turkey since I don't eat red meat and used my normal seasoning during the browning stage. text:
Par-boiling the peppers really makes this recipe shine!  No more too crunchy pepper with overcooked filling!  I use more seasoning than this recipe calls for - I like to add a bunch of Italian seasoning to the beef mixture.  I also prefer using pre-cooked frozen rice rather than uncooked rice whenever I can find it.  Then you can shorten the time the mixture simmers before adding it to the peppers.  I also like to mix my favorite spaghetti sauce into the beef/rice mixture in advance rather than pouring a can of bland (and super salty!) tomato sauce over the top.

text:
This recipe was a great starting point, but the second time I made them I definitely "kicked it up a notch."    I added 3 cloves of garlic, doubled the Worcestershire sauce, added a tablespoon of tomato paste, and added some cumin and cayenne.  I also substituted light cheddar for the cheddar.

If you soak the rice in a half cup of hot water while the meat mixture is cooking, it helps to soften the rice.  The first time I made them, the rice was still a little crunchy; second time (when I soaked the rice), it was perfect.

I also chose not to pre-cook the peppers, as we prefer them crunchy.

text:
It's cool to eat a meal in a pepper and it's surprising how filling those little rascals are.  I like dem stuffed bell peppers, mmm...hhmm!  My main concern while preparing this meal was to watch over the rice carefully.  While cooking the rice mixture, the water kept evaporating.  If you don't keep adding water, the rice may burn to the pan.  Also, you may want to cook the rice a bit longer than 15 minutes to get the rice more tender.  My wife was impressed with my cooking abilities.  This recipe made me look like a champ!

None
text:
I gave this recipe 5 stars even though I made some changes because the recipe would be good without changes. I usually make enough to freeze for future meals so the recipe was doubled. I didn't blanch the peppers because I don't like them mushy, and freezing tends to soften them anyway. I didn't salt the inside of the peppers as we don't need extra salt. I used basmati brown rice and cooked it separately in beef broth seasoned with garlic powder, onion powder, and cumin. I used canned diced tomatoes. It didn't make sense to get whole ones to chop. I also added 2 tsp. Italian seasoning and minced garlic to the beef mixture. The stuffed peppers were loved by my family, and they freeze very well. Each was wrapped in plastic wrap to prevent freezer burn, and then put into large baggies.

text:
This recipe was pretty good. I followed it as written. For flavor, I'd give it 5 stars,(definitely make sure to salt and pepper the beef to your liking while browning it because that makes a big difference for the overall outcome) but 4 overall because the rice was still hard. And I even cooked it over an hour to see if that would help, but it didn't! So, personally, these are the changes I'd make next time; use 1 cup cooked rice, Drain the can of diced tomatoes, and mix in the soup topping a bit throughout the beef mixture, as it did not seep through it. Then it will be perfect!

I absolutely loved these! This was the first time I ever tried to cook stuffed peppers. The main thing I didn't do was pre-boil the peppers. With using the soup as a topping, I had also made a little extra and poured it into the bottom of the pan before putting the peppers in it, and that softened up the peppers. I also added cheese before and after putting the tomato sauce on top of the meat and rice mixture; this way it had a little extra cheese and was nice to pull apart. I didn't have a onion, so I used minced onion and it worked fine. This is definitely something we will be having over and over again!

userID:
4252851
Display Name:
ash.schrantz
isPro:
False
followersCount:
2
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
3
favoritesCount:
76
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674139.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this recipe the other night, and, I have to admit, I'm glad that I instinctively made changes before I even begun..   First of all, boiling the peppers seemed a bit unnecessary to me- I didn't want my peppers mushy, so I didn't do that. (Great decision, by the way- the peppers came out just the right combination of cooked while retaining that firm texture and crunch that only fresh peppers have!) Also, changed what I put in; along with the proportions (though, to be fair, it depends on the size of your peppers, right?)  Instead of the condensed tomato soup, the water, and the whole tomatoes, I added a big jar of extra chunky tomato sauce, since I was pressed for time, mixing it in with the rice right after it was done cooking, and keeping it on low. I also added a bit of cayenne pepper, kept the Worcestershire.  Filled the peppers with the premixed beef & rice (made sure it was hot first) and slid into the oven- DID not add any cheese until the last minutes, when I slapped a slice of provolone over each pepper & cranked the oven up to 400 degrees; when the cheese was melted to the desired consistency, the peppers were done!  A tip: if you are like a few members in my family, and you really like these with a strong tomato taste, a lower sodium, easier solution than condensed soup would be tomato paste--because the worst you have to do is add a little water and boil it off if you feel you've added too much, and it really gives you the most flavor for the least effort.

text:
I love to cook and thought I would try this recipe since I have made stuffed green peppers for some time.  I thought it was a little unusual to sautee the meat and onions in a skillet (haven't heard of that), but I did and included tomato sauce instead of diced or stewed tomatos, even added shredded cheese and rice in the skillet.  Heated it on high for about 20 minutes until I knew it was cooked through.  Stuffing the peppers seemed easier and I used tomato soup on top (non-diluted).  I cooked them for about 45 minutes in the oven at 350 and they REALLY came out better than previous recipes I've tried.  They were not greasy at all and the consistancy of the meat inside was right on.  I really enjoyed them and encourage you to try it too.

text:
Good stuffed peppers.  The tomato soup is what makes the difference!  Istead of slicing off the tops, I sliced 4 peppers in half so I'd get 8 of them.  More stuffing, less pepper is how my kids like them.  I place the halved peppers in a 9 x 13 pan with about an inch of water in the bottom in the microwave for about 10 minutes ore more till they are tender.  Drain the water, fill the peppers and bake.  I tweaked the filling a bit.  Omitted the chopped tomatoes and added 2 tsp. of chili powder, some minced garlic and 1 tsp. garlic powder.  I topped with additional shredded cheese 5 minutes before pulling out of oven.

text:
Sigh...better than my Grandma's. Sorry, Grandma. This is the boeuf borguignon of stuffed pepper recipes...simple, nourishing and truly delicious. 

This recipe takes the same basic ingredients and adds these flourishes I am not used to (and was absolutely delighted by): pepper cooking method (they came out with that delicious well-cooked vegetable taste, that wasn't overcooked or too limp...it still had body and rich flavor and structure), sweet tomato soup (played so well with the other ingredients) and cheese in the stuffing mixture (gave the filling the consitution, body and flavor I always knew was missing from other recipes I'd tried, my mother's and grandmothers).

All in all a FANTASTIC recipe that, in my opinion, PERFECTS "comfort food" stuffed peppers. Not fancy, not anything but simple, good food, done perfectly.

text:
This is my regular recipe for stuffed peppers.  I use italian-style diced or stewed tomatoes, add garlic, and I always cook the rice seperately while the meat is browning.  They're both ready at about the same time and I just mix it all together in the end.  I top each filled pepper with tomato or pasta sauce, not soup. This is a great recipe that's very tweakable and always works.  Thanks!

None
text:
This recipe was great but I have a suggestion.  Once I cut the tops off the peppers and cleaned them out, I placed them, cut side down, in my steamer and steamed them rather than boiling them.  That way I didn't have to wait so long for the water to boil and they didn't get waterlogged.  I took them off the burner but didn't take off the lid until I was ready to stuff them.  They almost burned my fingers as I stuffed them but it was worth the trouble as I put them in the oven really almost ready to serve.  
  I should have put the seasonings in that have been mentioned.  My whole family loved them.  It was a real surprise.  I didn't expect the peppers to be popular.

text:
I really enjoyed these peppers. I changed things around. I used a mixture of different colors of bell peppers. I cut them in half instead. I used some suggestions from other users such as use pasta sauce instead of tomato soup, use double Worcestershire sauce, add dried basil and oregano. I added 2 cloves of minced fresh garlic and sauted it with the onion until translucent then added the ground meat and cooked until brown. Also, the first time I made this I used a mixture of ground beef, ground pork, and ground veal ( it was on hand in the fridge) and it tasted phenomenal. I cooked the rice 20 to 25 minutes as 15 min the rice was still crunchy.
I used 1 1/2 to 2 cups of cheese. 1 cup was added as per the directions and the other 1/2 to 1 cup sprinkled on top after peppers were stuffed.

text:
Really good recipe- haven't had stuffed peppers in years and these were great.  Two concerns with the recipe prompted me to make changes- cooking the rice first, and upping the spices/flavouring.  I added more worcestershire, basil, oregano, and minced garlic- lots of each.  I also used pizza sauce in with tomato sauce and tomato paste for the topping part (and didn't add water- definitely not needed).   I thought they were great- probably didn't even need the cheese on top.  Husband thought they were too saucy, but I liked it.  Would still be good even without the tomato sauce on top.  Thanks for this- I've never had a stuffed pepper with so much tomato/sauce actually- quite liked it!

text:
My boyfriend claims that this is his favorite meal EVER.  I served the meal with more rice and spooned the extra sauce over the rice.  I would make only a few changes (some of which have already been suggested by other reviewers).  (1) I cooked the rice before I put it into the meat mixture.  (2) Instead of putting all the meat in and then covering it with sauce, I treated the recipe more like a lasagna.  I put cheese on the bottom of the pepper, then a little meat, then tomato sauce, then more meat, then more tomato sauce, and finished it all off with the leftover cheese.

These peppers are great!  A few tweaks (cut peppers in half lengthwise, added panko on top before adding the soup, and I did use turkey meat instead, you really only need one can of soup, the other I used in the bowls).  
My hubby loved this European recipe as one he grew up with in Germany :)  and my daughter wants this made at every special occasion too now HA!
Serving suggestion:  I thought it would have had a little better presentation in a shallow bowl with the soup filled underneath the peppers.  When you cut into the pepper, the meat also mixed with the extra soup.  Yum!  They turned out delicious!

I changed most everything in this recipe, but the idea is still the same. text:
These were delish. I used brown rice as that is what we keep on hand. Brown rice does take a bit longer to cook so I did precook the rice in the same large pan for approx 15 mins until the liquid ( 1 cup h20-1/2 cup rice) was absorbed than I put the onions and the ground turkey ( another change) in the same pan to cook. Added the tomatoes and other ingrediants,stuffed the peppers and placed the whole pan in the oven. I am always figuring how to use less pots and pans. All the ingrediants including the peppers were cooked perfectly and the taste called for seconds.

text:
Tasted really good! I used half of a 28 out can of diced tomatoes and used the juice from that with one can of tomato soup (instead of two). I also added oregano and garlic which was good. I used the recipe for 6 peppers even though I only had 4 peppers (but they were large) and I barely had enough of the rice/beef mixture. Also, while cooking the rice, make sure to stir it and add extra moisture if needed, I almost burned it on medium heat (5/10). I think I'll try adding beef broth next time. I also forgot to add the cheese until I had already stuffed the peppers... oops. I mixed it in but I think it would have helped the cheese melt better if I had added it to the rice and beef before I had stuffed the peppers. Boiling the peppers before was definitely a great idea and I added cheese in the bottom of the peepers which was a great touch. Overall, we really liked it and will definitely do it again!

text:
I have used this recipe for Stuffed Peppers many times.  My family loves this version and I love the fact that the filling is fully cooked and in the pepper before hand.  For all the younger cooks out there, stuffed peppers were originally made using raw ground meat and cooked in the oven until fully done.  I've made three changes, I use onion cheese and I use a 28oz can of diced tomatoes, using one half in the filling and the other half in the sauce.  I also mince several garlic cloves and add to the mixture while cooking.   Aside from that I love the recipe as is.

text:
This was a good recipe, however, I also made some changes. I used 2 pounds of ground turkey instead of 1 pound of ground beef, I also seasoned the meat as it was cooking as I prefer the seasonings to be cooked into the meat, not added after it is cooked. I also used a can of diced tomatoes instead of whole, 1cup of rice and 1 cup of water instead of half a cup of each and used two 15 ounce (I think) cans of tomato sauce instead of tomato soup and water. I also added one 4 ounce can of sliced mushrooms to the mix. I also filled the peppers half way and tomato sauce then finished filling them and then topped off with more sauce. I forgot to mix the cheese into the filling so I just sprinkled it on top. I had extra filling so I just spread it in the pan around the peppers and also topped it with cheese and sauce. I found an ice cream scoop works well for filling the peppers. Very good, my dad very rarely has seconds and he ate two of them.

These are excellent stuffed peppers! I like that the green peppers and meat are pre-cooked. The peppers are tender without falling apart. To save time I just use a 14.5 oz can of diced tomatoes. I also use lean ground beef, and they work well with regular or reduced fat cheddar. When done I top with a little bit of cheese and broil on low for 2 minutes. Thanks, Suzanne.

text:
This recipe was absolutely delicious. The pepper was tender, the stuffing was fantastic and full of flavor. I did do some modifications to the original recipe to tweak the taste: doubled the Worcestershire sauce | added 1 tsp of basil and oregano to meat mixture | added two cloves of minced garlic to meat mixture. When layering the peppers, I went with (starting from the bottom) Cheese, Beef, Sauce, Beef, Cheese, Sauce. This made for an absolutely hearty dish that I will certainly make again.

text:
Usually the first time that I make a recipe I follow it as closely as possible. These were an exception which I decided to change to a mexican style dish. I seasoned the meat with a taco seasoning packet, used enchilada sauce instead of tomato soup and used diced mexican style tomatoes. I also followed other’s suggestions and put some of the sauce half way in the pepper, which helped to keep things moist. I then topped the peppers with more cheese and baked uncovered for 30 mins. The only change I will make next time is to use 1 cup of pre-cooked rice or use instant instead of long grain to speed things along. Great meal that I will use often, Thanks Suzanne

text:
This is a good start, but I did it different and everyone is begging for the recipe now.  I used RED and ORANGE bell peppers. They are sweeter.  Instead of white rice, I used Rice Roni Spanish rice. I cooked the rice, and sat it aside. Since the rice calls for a can of tomatoes you don't have to worry about adding them later. Then I saute the onion, and some garlic and set aside. Then cook the meat, drain, add rice (as much or little as you like), add onion and garlic, and then I add a can of whole sweet corn.  I put cheese at the bottom of the peppers, stuff them, then put cheese on the top of them. I then add the tomato soup!   ENJOY!

userID:
2693722
Display Name:
hwiggins
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/197190.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was really good but I made a few changes to it. I made this for 2 rather than the 6 the serving yields..... I don't understand why you are to boil the peppers for 5 minutes when they get fairly soft in the oven anyway so I didn't do this step. I cooked my onions and garlic in a dollop of real butter then added the ground beef cooked that through and added half a can of chopped tomatoes. I put a little more Worcestershire sauce, pepper, a good sprinkle of ground mustard, a pinch of thyme and a little paprika. Then instead of adding water....I think this makes any dish loose flavor...I added two tsp of tomato paste and stirred then turned off the heat and put half the cheese into the meat mixture and topped with the remaining cheese. I skipped the tomato soup altogether as I always add a little veg stock into the bottom of my pan  (just enough to cover the bottom) then put the peppers in so it has some moisture while cooking. The tomato paste gave it a great tomato flavor without being overpowering. These turned out delicious, they were moist enough but not overly "wet" and I got rave reviews on them. Oh before I forget I also cut the cook time down to 20 minutes at 180C/325F

text:
Great recipe, i made a few changes... I sauted the onions with 1 clove minced garlic and then added it to the meat after browning a bit added basil, oregeno and extra worchester sauce, i also cooked the rice seperate too. I took a couple of reviewers advice and filled the pepper up halfway with the meat mix, added some tomato soup, then more meat and topped it off with the remaining soup mixture. They turned out amazing, thank you!
Review:
Rating:
3
dateLastModified:
2009-03-11T10:40:40.173
helpfulCount:
3
userID:
3286403
Display Name:
landed
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
40
favoritesCount:
2002

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6750438.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This had way to much prep work due to pre cooking of ingredrients. 1st attempt I stuck by recipe instructions and the flavor wasn't there.  Second attempt I wanted flavor and smell I remember from childhood.  I decided not to pre cook the ingredients but add raw stuffing mixture to stuff peppers.  My end results on my second attempt at stuffed peppers was homemade comfort food flavor perfection. The green peppers do not have to be boiled prior to baking. The rice, onion and ground beef do not need to be cooked prior to stuffing the pepper.I increased oven temp to 375 and baking time to 1 1/2 to 1 3/4 hours. I used 3 medium green peppers and halved (6 servings), removed stem and seeds.I combined 1 pound raw ground burger (like you do when making meatloaf), 1/3 cup uncooked long grain rice such as basmati rice, 1/3 cup finely chopped raw onion, 1/4 teaspoon both oregano and basil, 1 tablespoon worcestershire sauce, dash of salt and pepper, and 1/2 can of a 15 oz can of tomato sauce. I mixed above ingredients and stuffed the half peppers.  I put peppers in a 9x13 baking dish then took the remaining 1/2 can of 15oz tomato sauce plus 1 full 15oz can of tomato sauce and combined in a bowl and used one of the cans to dilute the sauce with 1 full can of water then poured diluted sauce over peppers.  I covered peppers loosely with foil and basted the peppers every 20 minutes.  What a difference in flavor!

text:
It was a good entry and made a good meal with a green salad on the side.
I made few changes though.
Using the same big saucepan, I first, sauted chopped onions and garlic until soft, put them in a bowl. In the same saucepan I browned the ground beef, drained the fat, added salt and pepper, some italian seasoning and one can of diced tomatoes and green chilies (rotel) drained. I let the ground beef few more minutes on the strove for flavors to come together than transfered it in the bowl with the onion. Again in the same saucepan I cooked the rice in some water and the juice from Rotel. I mixed the rice with the ground beef and added the cheese. I stuffed the blanched peppers with the mix and put them in a ovenproof dish. I used only 1 can of tomato soup dilueted with 1/2 cup of water.

text:
These turned out delicious, but I did make some changes based on some of the reviews I read and my own preferences.

We did 2 red/2 green/2 yellow peppers for variety.  I added 1 tsp garlic, 1 tsp oregano, 1 tsp thyme, and 1 tsp basil to the meat for some added flavor.  I also didn't waste the tops of the peppers and chopped any extra bits of pepper off them (not stems of course)and tossed into meat mixture.  Finally, I also added 2+ Tbs. of tomato paste and 2 handfuls of chopped fresh spinach to the mixture, as well as omitted the cheese (didn't want the extra fat).  Just sprinkled a very light dusting of parm on top.  Very quick, easy, and delicious for a weeknight meal.

Great recipe altho I did change & add some things.  For the green peppers, after cleaning them, I microwaved, cut side down, 4 minutes on high with a little water on the bottom of the glass dish.  I browned 1 pound pork chorizio (sp?) (it's what I had in the freezer), then added 2 onions, 1 cup uncooked rice, 1 cup water, 2 teaspoons worcestshire cooked for almost 15 minutes.  Removed from heat & added 2 cups shredded mexican cheese & instead of tomato soup I used a 26-1/2 oz can of spagetti sauce (half in the meat mixture & half on top after stuffing peppers).  Baked covered 25-30 minutes.  Will definetely make again.

text:
The only reason I gave this 4 * is because I changed and added a couple of things. This is a good recipe for those who have never made stuffed peppers before. It's quick and easy.  I mixed Sausage and Hamburger together to give the mixture some taste. I added chopped onion, seasoning salt,Italian Seasoning into the meat mixture. Do not cook the meat before adding it into the Peppers. It will be cooked well in the oven. This will prevent you from losing a lot of needed flavor that you lose when cooking the meat first.   Also, make sure that you use the Tomato Soup. It does give it the needed flavoring. Thanks for sharing Joe

text:
This is a pretty good recipe.  The tomato soup wasn't bad, but as my sister put it, it made it taste like hamburger helper.  Next time I think I'll pour a good tomato sauce or even a can of peeled chopped tomatoes.  That will give it more of a fresh taste.  Also, I've noticed that people are saying that it's kind of bland and needs more spices - well since this mixture is cooked before it is stuffed into the pepper, you need to taste it first and adjust the spices accordingly.  Never go by a recipe exactly since different people have different tastes.  If it needs more spices, add them!

This was one of the first recipes I kept off of allrecipes a few years ago.  
Instead of using the can of tomatos, I sub 1 can tomato paste and 1 can of tomato sauce. Instead of 2 cans of tomato soup, I use only one, otherwise it will be soupy. And the only other modification is that I blanche the peppers in half the time (2.5 minutes), or they will become bitter.

text:
Had this for dinner tonight.  My husband rated it a 4, and my son rated it a 5 without the peppers, but an overall 4.  Reading the reviews, I was hopeful that my ultra-finicky 3 year old would try it, but she refused.  I changed the recipe slightly and really liked the changes.  I added some oregano and garlic salt for flavor to the meat mixture.  I also cut the peppers in half and stuffed them.  I think there was too much water, as I didn't drain the canned tomatoes, and I ended up having to drain some liquid before I stuffed the peppers.  The only real change I made was that I didn't have any tomato soup, so I used a small can of tomato sauce and added about 1/4 cup of brown sugar to it, I then poured this over each pepper.  It added a wonderful flavor, as the sauce sunk down into the meat mixture and baked.  Very yummy!

text:
I made these stuffed peppers for my family. I followed advise from other reviewers: cutting the peppers in half lengthwise, adding a can of diced tomatoes (I used tomato with diced jalapenos), adding garlic to the meat, and I doubled the worcestershire sauce. I cooked a box of beef flavored rice before adding it to the meat (I didn't have to season with salt and pepper). I added tomato soup inside the peppers before filling with meat. Also, I used yellow, orange, and green peppers; all were tasty and varied in flavor. My family really liked the recipe, only was missing texture. I think next time I will top the peppers with Parmesan cheese, for added crunch.

country:

text:
This is a good starter recipe but it lacked enough flavor in my opinion. 

I know it sounds terrible but I originally wanted to make these because I fell in love with Stouffer's version and wanted a homemade comparable. I still like the flavor of the Stouffer's ones more after making this without any changes (pretty bad, I know).

Next time I will probably try these things:
- Boil peppers a little longer to make a tad softer.
- Use tomato sauce instead of tomato soup
- More water needed to cook rice, or use 1/2 the tomato sauce instead of or w/ water to add flavor
- Use diced tomatoes instead of whole
- Add Italian Seasoning to taste (about 1/2 tsp)
- Add Garlic Powder to taste (about 1/2 tsp)
- Add Seasoned Salt to taste (about 1/2 tsp)
- Add more Worcestershire sauce
- Add Soy sauce (same amnt as Worcestershire)
- More cheese maybe or Italian blend kind?
~ Play w/ flavors more to get it perfect.

But like I said it's a good start.

Served with Golden Sweet Cornbread recipe muffins and a simple tossed salad (1 romaine head, 1/2 red onion, 1 tomato, 1/4 shredded carrot, and shredded cheddar).

text:
My family loves this recipe, including my daughter who doesn't usually like bell peppers. I subbed ground beef with lean turkey, I subbed white salt with seasoned salt, sautéed 2 cloves of fresh garlic along with the onions and turkey, added Italian seasoning to the meat mixture and doubled the Worcestershire sauce. After stuffing each pepper, I topped with pasta sauce (roasted garlic Preggo) instead of tomato soup. I then used any additional cup of cheese to top each stuffed pepper, then finished each off with Italian seasoning. It was great. I served with Grandmother's Buttermilk Cornbread, another grey recipe from allrecipes.com. Such a wonderful meal. My daughter says it is the only thing better than In N Out Burgers' animal style fries. Haha

I have been making this recipe for years. It is very moist and great tasting with the cheese added. I usually add more onions, and worcestershire sauce. Very good dish. I think I will follow one suggestion to microwave the peppers, instead of putting them in boiling water. This will save time.
4-3-19... fill the peppers half way with meat mixture, then add some soup mixture, then top off the pepper with more meat mixture.  They come out so much more moist this way ,instead of just putting the soup just on top.

text:
I thought it was more than a wonderful base recipe.  We all take recipes & tweak to our own taste buds, so that is what I did.  I increased the onion to one half, added a stalk of celery, two garlic cloves chopped & as others suggested extra Worcestershire  sauce.  I used one cup "cooked" rice, Rotel diced fired roasted tomatoes with chilis, cayenne pepper, a little italian seasong (dont know why, just cause i use it allot) seasoning salt, lemon pepper, 1/2 can of Mexican corn. In the end, i just added the tomato soup to the entire mixture.  All was done taste testing along the way of course.  This lovely mixture was generously stuffed into brightly colored yellow and orange par boiled peppers.   Then before putting in the oven, topping with yummy ooey gooey cheese & crunchy panko  crumbs.   Mmmmmmm,  the elation of my taste buds say "its a keeper"!  Because I used more hamburger than recommended & other additions that increased the quantity, I had some left over stuffing.  I labeled this & put into the freezer for some day when I need a short cut meal.

text:
I think this recipe was absolutely wonderful! My family devoured these stuffed peppers in no time. I am giving this recipe five stars because full credit goes to the person who posted the recipe with a few minor adjustments that I made. The few things I changed were: As I was frying the beef mixture and onion, I added minced garlic. I used already diced fire roasted tomato's by hunts instead of using whole tomato's and having to chop them, I used beef broth to add to the flavor instead of using water, I used Ragu Garden Combination instead of tomato sauce(again, adding to flavor). Also, half way through stuffing the peppers, I put a little of the Ragu Garden combination in the middle with a smidget of cheese. As for the seasonings like the salt and pepper, I did season to my taste, adding one basil leaf or you can sub using a dash of crushed basil. This recipe was full of flavor by the time I finished adding my touches and this recipe will definitely be a keeper for me and my family. Thank you!

text:
I used this recipe and the reviews i read as a base and added/made changes to my liking. after the changes, the stuffed peppers tasted AMAZING! I cut the recipe in half, here are my changes - I used brown rice (which i precooked separately in chicken broth for more flavor) ground turkey instead of beef, and  half a can diced tomatoes with Italian seasoning. i omitted the W sauce cause i didnt have any. I cooked the beef with the onions and garlic, then i seasoned the mixture with a dash of garlic powder,dried basil,seasoning salt,pepper. I then added the tomatoes and also a tablespoon of ketchup (from another review). i opened the tomato soup and mixed it with some milk to make a more creamy sauce and also added some seasoning to that (dried parsley,garlic powder,dried minced onions)and put a few heaping spoonfuls of the "sauce" into the beef. then i added the cooked rice and added a small bunch of fresh chopped cilantro (this REALLY added to the dish!!!) I then added italian cheese instead of cheddar, layered half a slice of pepper jack cheese on the bottom of the green peppers and then added the mixture. topped off with more sauce and cheese and a sprinkle of bread crumbs. THIS DISH BLEW OUR MIND! we LOVED IT! and it was so filling and delicious.. will be making again. i know i made lots of changes, but thank you so much for the base recipe!

I cooked the rice separately.  And cooked the ground beef with onions.  While the beef & onions were draining, I microwaved the peppers for 3 minutes.  I cut them in half prior.  Then I mixed the rice, beef mixture, already diced tomatoes (Rotel brand - HOT - one can), & Worcestershire sauce (used 2 tsp) and 1/4 cup pasta sauce.  I poured pasta sauce in the bottom of the baking dish, then added the peppers with cheese before I added the stuffing, then topped with remaining cheese.  I baked at 350 until the cheese was bubbling.  My husband loved it!  I will definitely make again.  I may use a different cheese or combination of cheeses next time.

This was excellent. I took the advice of reviewers and added the soup halfway through and then topped off the peppers with it as well. I added minced garlic to the meat mix and used italian seasoned canned tomatoes and used an italian cheese mix to the top instead of cheddar. It was REALLY good! Instead of water in the mix, I actually used the juices from the can of seasoned tomatoes.

text:
This recipe was a great starting point for me.  I switched it up a little...I used ground turkey instead of beef...I used diced tomatoes instead of whole peeled tomatoes...I used more than a teaspoon Worcestershire sauce (not sure how much just poured some in)...I used mozzarella cheese instead of cheddar cheese (personal preference)...used Classico tomato and basil sauce instead of tomato soup

Also, while browning my meat, I used a little seasoning salt, pepper, garlic powder, and accent…

I stirred some of the mozzarella cheese in as well as sprinkled some on top before baking...
I also parboiled the peppers for about 10-15 minutes instead of 5 minutes...

All-in-all this was a great recipe and the peppers were delicious...my fiancé said that this is something that I can cook for him every week!!

text:
A good solid recipe.  I felt it could be a great recipe with a few tweaks to the meat filling.  I found it to be a touch on the bland side.  I added some garlic powder and some oregano and that improved the flavor a great deal.  I would also recommend some more shredded cheddar.  One cup virtually disappeared into the meat mixture.  Another cup or so would have given it a nice cheesy consistency.  All in all, however, a good strong recipe and I will be working with it again in the future.

these were my first attempt at stuffed peppers. I modified the recipe a bit- used 2 regular tomatoes diced up, brown rice (cooked separately and added into cooked meat & onions), fresh minced garlic, and one can tomato soup added to meat & rice mixture without adding any water. cooked for 20 min. and they were perfect! gave it 4 stars only because it did not have a ton of 'wow' flavor which I think if made with sausage it may have. Overall- I would make these again!

I made a few changes: turkey (85/15) instead of beef, cut the peppers lengthwise, used only 3 (large) peppers, used a whole onion and 5 cloves of minced garlic, didn't drain turkey/onion mixture, used diced tomatoes with oregano and basil, added basil, rosemary, and sage that I had on hand from the garden, and baked uncovered.

The final product was very good.  I was full from one half pepper.  I will definitely make this again.

text:
Made these last night and was pleasantly surprised with my end product.  I thought they were easy to make and flavorful.  I used 1 1/2 lbs of lean ground beef and it was just enough for 6 peppers.  For more flavor I would use ground chuck or a 85% lean ground meat.  I also used a can of already crushed tomatoes and it worked well, bascically to cut back on the time.  Of course I added extra cheddar cheese which topped them of perfectly.  This was my first attempt at stuffed peppers and am satisfied with the flavor, ease of preparing them and relatively inexpensive to make.  Completely satisfied.  Enjoy!!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
OMG! improv is great. Started with the basics  here but instead of beef and rice, I substituted a brand name "dirty rice" mix.  While the rice mix was cooking, I rubbed olive oil on 4 large green peppers and placed them in a 350 oven (20 min). Used 1 can diced tomatoes (salt free) and 1 can tomato soup which smoothed out the sauce. When the dirty rice was ready, filled 4 peppers to the brim, poured on sauce and returned to oven for 35 mins. @ 350. Served with mashed red potatoes with garlic. Magnificent and no additional spice needed. The olive oil rub left some crispy to the peppers.  Great!

text:
i am extremely disappointed that the rice never fully cooked even after cooking the peppers in the oven for 45 minutes!  What a waste!  I vegetarianized the recipe. I used soy crumbles instead of ground meat. I also used lots of garlic, basil and oregano. I also boiled the peppers for 5 minutes prior to stuffing. I punctured holes in the bottoms of the peppers so it wasn't too soupy like a previous review said. i also added soy cheese instead of regular cheese. I added 1/4 cup of red wine to the "meat" and onions while they cooked.   i think if i had used frozen precooked rice, this recipe would have been fantastic.

text:
This was my first attempt at stuffed peppers, I thought it was a good base recipe but disliked some aspects of it. After reading some reviews I decided to add some garlic in while browning the meat, also a bit of sage, and a bay leaf. I used diced tomatoes insteaded of whole because I find the look a bit more refined; also used beef broth instead of water. The rice could have cooked for a bit longer than 15 minutes , I used long grain rice and although it was cooked it stil had a bit of crunch to it . After cooking I added the cheese to the mixture, half filled the pepper and added some of the diluted tomato soup the filled the rest, topped with more tomatoe soup and a bit of parmesan cheese. I feel the tomato soup made it taste cheap, next time I will make my own tomato sauce; thats one of the main things I didnt like about it.

text:
SOOO GOOD...only if you add a lot more flavor.  i added 6 garlic cloves along with the onion and beef.  then added 1t. basil, 1t. oregano, 1t. thyme and doubles the worcestershire.  then to make it super easy, i added the tomato soup with diced tomatoes and cookeduntil gravy-esk.  i browned the peppers on the BBQ for 10 mins instead of boiling (adds tons more flav), assembled everything, then popped in the broiler till cheese was bubbly.  this way you dont have to cook for another 35 mins.  faster and easier!

This was a great recipe!  My husband could not stop commenting on how great they were!  What I did differently:
4 lg green peppers; I used a lb of ground beef that was prepackaged for meatloaf from the meat counter; 1 cup of boil in a bag rice; 3/4 cup water; can of diced tomatoes seasoned instead of whole tomatoes; and used a jar of spaghetti sauce in place of the soup.

It has a lot of potential, but wasn't as flavorful as I was expecting.  I made it vegetarian by using Morningstar Farms "beef" crumbles. Next time I will add more seasonings to the "beef" like crushed red pepper, minced garlic, and probably some oregano and thyme.  Overall, a very good starter recipe that I'll customize.

text:
Turned out wonderful!  I used fresh from the garden green peppers.  I followed the basic recipe, but did make minor changes.  I did not boil the peppers ahead. I did cooked the rice ahead so I did not add water.  I also used fresh diced tomatoes, also from the garden, in place of canned tomatoes.  At the end substituted pasta sauce in place of tomato soup.  Since I didn't boil the peppers ahead, I did bake longer in the oven. I will make this again. Great basic recipe

This was delicious. I didn't precook my peppers, I just baked this until the peppers were tender (about 15 minutes longer). I left out the canned tomatoes and added some of the tomato soup instead. Thanks Suzanne for posting this!

First off, I do not like bell peppers, but I LOVE this dish. I don't eat the peppers but the stuffing inside is the best. The only thing I change is: I use more Worcestershire sauce (probably 1 1/2 - 2 tablespoons) and season the meat with garlic powder, garlic salt and cumin while it's simmering, I add sliced mushrooms, use stewed tomatoes, and cheddar & Garlic Mozzerella (made by sargento's and is oh so yummy!). Thank you so much for the excellent recipe!!

text:
The 1st time I made this recipe I followed it to a T, the 2nd time I made I changed a few things and it was AWESOME....

I used 2 lbs ground meat 1 large white onion
1 can (28 oz) crushed tomatoes 1 cup water 1 cup rice LOTS of garlic powder, salt, pepper and a few shakes of ground red pepper.  I also used a bag of shredded mexican cheese.  It was THE BOMB.  I had extra stuffing, which I planned since my yongest kids do not like the peppers and I baked it in the oven next to the pepper just took it out 15 minutes early.

I hope you like my variation!

Steph

mmmm tasty! my boyfriend loved this one. He would rate a 5 and I would rate a 4 ONLy because I don't like bell peppers that much. the inside was awesome though. I used extra lean turkey meat, low fat cheese (colby and jack) i think next time i'll use cheddar. I also added chicken flavoring powder, oregano, parsley and garlic salt. text:
Very good stuffed bell peppers.  I have made this dish several times with some adjustments made.  I use tomato sauce instead of water, I add a can of corn and I put a few dashes of taco sauce in the mix to add a zing to it.  The taco sauce does not make it spicy, but it adds more flavor.  Also, you need to spice it up a bit with onion and garlic powder otherwise there will not be much flavor.  The way I make it turns out perfect.  My husband and daughter beg for this dish at least once or twice a week.  Delicious!!!!

Excellent!  My husband loved it.  Made a few changes, though...did things the "hard" way.  Used twice as much onion, diced fresh tomatoes (1 3/4 cups), and precooked Jasmine rice (2 cups). text:
I agree with “Rouver” in that I would add some more Worcestershire Sauce, some Italian herbs & fresh garlic to fill out the flavor profile. I also concur that it’s silly to buy a can of whole tomatoes and THEN dice them (unnecessary work) when the grocery already has diced tomatoes for this very purpose.I will make again with less or no tomato soup as unnecessary for my needs and taste. Campbell’s Tomato Soup is too iconic and recognizable (as in 1950’s) a flavor for me.

text:
Delish recipe - reminds me of Mom's.  One change - we always roast the pepper a little (not boil).  Adds a great flavor and helps start the peppers cooking.  One tidbit based on another reviewer's note on why would you use whole tomatoes and dice them - the best tomatoes are packed whole.  The inferior tomatoes are used for diced and crushed.

text:
We really liked this. I used a combination of red and yellow peppers because that's what I had.  My filling filled 3 peppers to the brim and I only threw out a few tbsp of filling but the peppers were the big ones from Costco. I used 1/2 ground beef and 1/2 spicy Italian sausage (again, that's what I had).  I also used tomato sauce instead of tomato soup.  I had to cook the rice for 5 min longer, so 20 min. I saved a bit of the cheese and after the 25 min in the oven, I topped the peppers with cheese and broiled the cheese on the peppers until it bubbled.  While the peppers were baking, I made pasta.   I took the peppers out of the sauce after broiling and mixed the pasta in the sauce.  my 1 year old liked this too.

This was a great recipe! I added garlic, oregano, basil, thyme, cumin, cayenne, and pepper to the beef/onion mixture. And used beef broth instead of water. Display Name:
NCFORD70

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1414562.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I enjoyed this dish but made several changes based on the reviews. I added fresh garlic and Italian seasoning to add more flavor to the meat mixture. I also cut the peppers lengthwise instead of cutting the tops off since that seems wasteful. Since we're trying to be healthy I used brown rice (success boil in the bag bout of the bag added to beef mixture) and ground turkey. I used onion powder instead of onions because my hubby doesn't care for onion too much but I like the flavor. I didn't use tomato soup, too much sodium (hubby has high blood pressure) and used tomato paste diluted with water and seasoned with Mrs. Dash, pepper and onion powder. I added Rotel with diced chilies and a can of diced tomatoes instead of whole tomatoes chopped up. (I'm efficient not lazy) ?? I also layered the ingredients in the peppers as another reviewer suggested in the following order, sauce, meat mixture, cheese. Turned out great and I will make it again. The next time I plan to add sausage for more zip!

None
text:
Good overall. I split the peppers in half lengthwise--easier to get the ribs and seeds out. I used a can of diced tomatoes, incl. the liquid. I doubled the Worcestershire sauce and added some Italian seasoning--might have been a bit bland without it. For the sauce, I used a 32-oz. carton of Imagine tomato soup. I didn't cover the dish in the oven, but I think it turned out better that way--some of the liquid in the soup evaporated, making it thicker.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674130.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm only giving this recipe 4 stars because of the headache it caused from using the uncooked rice as directed. To save yourself the hassle of having hard, undercooked rice, COOK THE RICE AHEAD of time then add it to the mixture!  Aside from the rice fiasco the recipe IS good.  I followed others recommendations of  sautéing a Tablespoon or more of minced garlic with the meat, using diced tomatoes,  doubling the Worcheser sauce, using beef broth instead of the 1/2 cup of water and adding some Italian seasoning. I also chopped up a whole bag of baby spinach and added it with the mixture for extra flavor, texture, color and nutrients. This is a good base recipe but I think it would come out rather bland if you don't add your own extra seasonings to it.

text:
Outstanding!  Added 2 t. Worcestershire and 1/2 cup beef bouillon to meat mixture.   Also added 1/4 t. each of oregano and basil. I also cooked my rice before adding to HB mixture.  Heated tomato soup with 1/2 cup water and added approx. 1/2 soup to HB mixture before filling. Partially cooked peppers in microwave before filling.  Topped with remaining soup.  Cooked covered for 45 minutes.  Removed and sprinkled with cheese.  Will definitely make again!  Cskitchen

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Lovely recipe, thanks!  I tweaked it a bit … not keen on green peppers so I used orange and yellow instead and I didn't boil the peppers (totally skipped the first step) since they will be baked and prefer a crisp texture when plated.  I also 'kicked it up a notch' because of the comments re: flavour.  I added a dash of Frank's Hot Sauce after frying the beef and onions, 1 clove of diced garlic and taco & cajun seasoning on top of the cheese.  I added a can of 'fire roasted' diced tomatoes and used cheese in the mixture, as noted in the recipe, but I also added more old cheddar cheese on top of the tomato sauce.  I used 4 peppers and approx. 3/4 cup hamburger, 1/2 onion and 1/2 cup uncooked rice which cooked nicely while simmering in the pan.  I baked then broiled the stuffed peppers.  We really enjoyed this dish!

text:
Definately a hit in my household. I did take some shortcuts to ensure speed. I cooked the rice separately and then just incorporated into the cooked seasoned meat when it was done. Also, instead of a tomato soup, I just used a medium can of tomato sauce - I find that it doesn't have as much seasonings so you better control of your flavors. The best part is that kids love the insides. So when one requested just the inside and not the pepper, I just put some to the side and it makes a good meal all on it's own.

text:
Loved this.  I changed it up just a bit for flavor preferences. I used a 14.5 oz can of tomato sauce instead of the soup, and I added Italian seasoning to it.  I used diced organic tomatoes instead of the whole peeled tomatoes, and I included the liquid.  I used less cheese only because I don't recall my mom using cheese in her peppers when I was a kid and I didn't know how it would taste.  I think the cheese doesn't add a whole lot of flavor but it helps everything stick together.  I added two cloves of minced garlic to the beef and onions for more flavor. It was quite good and made great lunch leftovers!

text:
This recipe was so good and easy to make.  I added 3 cloves of garlic, fresh basil, corn, cilantro, lime juice, and vegetarian crumbles instead of ground beef.  I also used a can of crushed tomatoes with lime and chile peppers.  I used traditional spaghetti sauce instead of tomato soup. I also used steam in a bag brown rice, sautéed the onion, garlic, finely chopped carrots, and mixed all together with the crumbles for the stuffing. I layered cheese, then the stuffed ingredients, then sauce, in the peppers, then topped with Parmesan cheese. So good, with a kick of spice!

We love this recipe and make it at least once a month. The only changes I make now is to use the rice cooker for the rice because I'm notorious for under cooking the rice, which is no fault of the recipe. Other than that I made it just as written. The other change is that I use three large green peppers instead of six since there are only three of us. Makes an entire meal!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I modified this recipe to my family's liking, but since it's so similar, I gave it a five star review. First, I cut the tops off five green peppers, and cleaned them out. I cooked up a 1/2 cup instant rice. In another pan,heated a can of tomato soup with water. Next, I took 1 1b hamburg meat, diced onion, not measuring, just adding enough to my liking. I also added black pepper, and garlic powder. Next, I added the rice, and mixed together. Then I stuffed all the peppers, put them in a casserole dish, and poured the tomato soup over them. I bake at 350 degrees, for 1 hour. I just put them together, and they are in the oven for tonight's supper. We'll have it with rye bread and a salad. This is a family favorite, one I learned from my Mother.

This is a pretty good recipe, but it is very bland as written; it tasted like a meatloaf wrapped in cellulose. It's more like a recipe foundation for tweaking. text:
I agree with some of the recommended changes.  My family and friends also prefer the red, orange or yellow peppers over the green peppers.  I find frying the onions first works better for me in most recipes.  I placed the peppers in the microwave to soften them, but boiling them also works well.  I used 500 g beef and 250 g pork, also spicy tomatoe  sauce rather than tomatoe soup.  I used a bag of shredded white cheeses and added them to the bottom of each half pepper first than added a bit more on the top of each pepper.  This recipe is a keeper for me.

Basic above plus added (for quantity as above) 2 long thin red hot peppers without seeds and very finely chopped and chopped up the bell pepper tops (without stem of course) and cooked it in the meat along with a cup of spicy round peppers (do not have in states). text:
I've made this recipe a few times and we love it. I usually use ground turkey instead of ground beef. I also add a little more seasoning to the meat & rice mixture, like garlic and italian seasonings, and I also double the worcestershire sauce because we like it. I also use tomato sauce in place of the tomato soup and put a spoonful inside the peppers before filling them, so the sauce is throughout the filling when you eat it. Tonight when I made them, I had the meat already cooking when I realized I was out of rice, so I used orzo instead and doubled the amount of water, then still let it simmer 15 or until the orzo was tender. It still turned out great!

Elise Carole Boucher

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I adjusted this primarily because I did not have the exact ingrediants on hand. 1)  I did not boil the peppers before hand, and thus, they baked to the green pepper version of "al dente," which is fine, because I dislike the mushy quality of most stuffed peppers. 2} Filling: browned a pound of ground turkey, then added two fresh tomatoes, salt, peper, smoked paprika to taste, and 1/4 cup of rhubarb ketchup (the recipe is on all recipes, look 'er up!) and enough water to let the tomatoes cook down into a sauce, cooked it off. Used pree-cooked rice, added after the sauce was finished.Topped with colby cheese. 3} Substituted about 2.5 cups of spaghetti sauce andf thinned with a little more water to gravy consistency for baking. Because I changed the recipe so much, I only gave this one a 4-star rating as I didn't find out what the actual recipe was like. However, as a guide for getting good stuffed peppers with what you have on hand, this recipe was perfect. I never made stuffed peppers before and these came out great, thanks to the guidance in this recipe.

text:
This is a great recipe.  I've had to make a few adjustments to easily scale it to 2 people: 2 peppers, 1 can tomato soup, 200g ground meat, 1 small chopped red onion, 2tbsp rice, 2 tbsp water, 1/4 cup cheese, and a few squirts worchester sauce.  Salt and pepper to taste.  Followed all the directions as-is, except I just add the whole can of tomato soup to the meat/rice, and don't worry about pouring it over the top.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I saved this recipe because of the base ingredients! It really makes for a delicious stuffed green pepper. 

However, I cook the rice separately, then mix it with the tomatoes, meat and spice. This is because of past experiences where the rice just does not get cooked enough otherwise...

I rinse off the ground beef after cooking and before mixing to get rid of excess fat! (You can make 80% lean into 90%+ lean this way.) 

I use about 3/4 of the cheese in the mix, and add the rest on top at the end of cooking. 

Yum yum yum yum!!

text:
Really Good recipe!! I had a little hickup though. I would not recommend cooking the rice with the meat. I read other reviews saying this, but figured i would be a rebel and try it out. Fail! I also used brown rice, so this problably contributed to the length of time it took to get  tender, but next time i will play it safe and cook the rice (white or brown) separately. I had to cook the meat/rice combo for about 30/35 min, adding more water mix w/tomato soup a couple times. Even then, my rice was not completely cooked, but i went ahead and  stuffed my peppers and stuck 'em in the oven.

Display Name:
Peggy Marshall
