photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1472845.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I never liked my mothers peppers with tomato paste...so I stuff peppers-( green and red ) with  browned ground beef, salt, pepper and garlic,  add sauted mushrooms-chopped ( and one whole mushroom poked down into top of pepper) add  par-boiled rice, add a little cream of mushroom soup to hamburger mix and stuff peppers -(which have been boiled,
 drained and rinsed with cold water to stop cooking,  Lightly stuff peppers with meat mixture,  poke a chunk  of swiss cheese into middle and add a  mushroom and a slice  of swiss cheese to top of pepper).  tastes real good.  oh, and pour the rest of soup over peppers and bake in a dutch oven with lid. Note: always boil pepper first-drain,rinse with cold water, and partially cooked rice (instant rice gets too mushy)

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are ok.  I have made them twice.  The first time I follwed the recipe exactly and my husband loved them with the exception of the worcestershire sauce(He doens't like that stuff).  He prefered the inside because it was a little drier.  The next time I only used one can of soup and mixed some of it in with the meat.  I also added some seasoning because I thought the first time was a little bland.  So it definitely would be if I left out the Worcestershire sauce.  Everyone liked it....my kids loved it much more the second time....as did I.  My husband liked the taste better, but still prefered it drier like the first time.  So I guess it is all a matter of opinion.  Oh, you do only need one can of soup...2 is definitely too much.  If you don't mind the peeling, buy diced tomatoes.  I add a lot more cheese, because everybody loves more cheese.

userID:
208226
Display Name:
Jenn Haney

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1142408.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent recipe. I will def be making these again. I didn't alter the recipe much. I like my peppers a little on the sweet side so I threw a tbsp or so of sugar into the boiling water with my peppers. I used ground turkey 97% lean (to make it a little more diet friendly).  I also didn't follow the boiling time of the peppers.  Everyone's peppers aren't going to be created equal. Pepper thickness will vary and therefore the time it takes to get them slightly tender will also vary. I cooked the peppers until they were able to be pierced fairly easily with a fork. Keep in mind when testing your peppers that they will be also cooking in the oven for 35 minutes so don't overcook them when boiling. Other than the above, no changes were made and the end result was DELICIOUS! The only reason my family of three (myself included) had one pepper leftover was because we were STUFFED.  : )  But I had that leftover pepper for lunch today and it was still amazing.

Double the rice, onion and worcestershire sauce.
Add garlic, black pepper, basil and oregano.
Halve the condensed tomato soup; mix part into stuffing mixture, pour remainder on top.

I might also recommend reducing the total amount of stuffing or doing an extra 2-3 peppers (especially if adding extra rice), as peppers were, in my opinion, overstuffed (even with stock recipe).

photo:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've been making Stuffed Green Peppers for a long time but wanted to try this recipe because it had so many reviews. I don't believe that this is one of those recipes you can really mess up so I used the ingredients as suggested (with a few minor changes) and cooked the peppers in a crockpot. This is the way I've always cooked them and they always turn out great. (The peppers however are probably much softer than by baking them a shorter period of time) I put all the ingredients (raw) in a bowl and mixed together. I did add garlic, more worcestershire and corn. I limited the salt because the cheese adds plenty. I drained the tomato juice in with the tomato soup instead of using water then mixed the tomatoes in with meat mixture. I also used ground sirloin so that the peppers would not fill up with grease on top as I did not cook meat before stuffing peppers. It's done about 4-5 hours. Quite honestly I've never prepared peppers in the oven before but maybe next time I will try it just to compare.

text:
Recipe has great potential, but few things I had to adjust. First, boiling the peppers for 5-10 minutes was not enough to soften them so they only needed to bake for 25-30 minutes. I would recommend boiling them for at least 15-20 minutes. When i did bake them, I heated the oven to 375 and cooked for a good 45 minutes until they were tender. Other than that recipe was great!

text:
For a Low Carb version of this recipe, I omitted the rice and added shredded cabbage. I used 1 cup of shredded cabbage for each cup of cooked rice omitted. Simply saute shredded cabbage into the meat mixture before filling peppers. Makes this enjoyable for people who are on no carb/low carb diets. Cabbage has approx. 5 grams of carbs per 1 cup, shredded. Enjoy!

text:
My husband and I enjoyed these; I made ones for the kids (4, 1) out of the peppers in ramekins, which they also enjoyed. I took the advice of other reviewers; added some additional garlic and Italian seasoning to the hamburger while cooking, and for the stuffing process, I sprinkled some cheese in the bottom of the peppers, followed by layers of hamburger, gravy, hamburger, gravy, then topped it off with cheese. I used both red and green peppers; we enjoyed both equally. The only thing I didn't love; peppers are $1.99 each at the store right now, making this a pricey dish.

This was delicious--after a few minor adjustments. I doubled the Worchestershire sauce as advised, used tomato sauce instead of water when simmering the ingredients together, and added half a can of corn and half a can of kidney beans. This added a little more flavor, color, and protein. I also put a little bit of cheddar cheese in the bottom of the peppers. I think the tomato sauce made the biggest difference though. Yum!

text:
This recipe is a good base. However, to make it work, I had to modify it cosiderably. I cut the bell peppers lengthwise. Used only one can of tomato soup. Cooked the rice seperately as well as the meat. Added some minced garlic, cumin, chili powder, and oregano; and omitted the worsteshire sauce and 1/2 cup water (I just added a full soup can's worth instead). I mixed the soup into the stuffing, instead of pouring it over the peppers. It came out wonderful.

I made some modifications as well. Instead of waiting to pour tomato sauce over the peppers, I actually mixed it with the beef and rice and let it on low heat for 3-5 min. https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/570354.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
4 stars because this appears bland as written. A quick & neat idea: If you have leftovers from a mexican meal, i.e. spanish rice, fresh salsa, etc. use it up mixed w/grn beef & some crumbled Queso cheese and a spoon of sour cream mixed together before stuffing. I had fresh cilantro I needed to use up as well in this. I like the par cooking of green peppers 1st so they are a bit softer and more mellow. Try red peppers which are a bit sweeter and no need to precook those. Since I was only making two peppers I put them in a pyrex meatloaf type dish where I added 1/2 C chicken stock with 2 tblsp ketchup to the bottom. I baked mine covered w/foil for 30 minutes and then topped with shredded cheese and baked uncovered until cheese melted. More of a Mexican flavor but great way to use up some leftover ingredients from a different meal and can be quickly thrown together.

country:
None
text:
This is a great recipe following others advice to simplify process and season up to our taste this is a 5 star plus recipe.  Changes made: (1) preheat oven and bake peppers while preparing next steps if you like soft bell peppers.  I precooked the halves 25-30 minutes and they were soft for my picky husband.  (2)  Browned ground veal (what I had) with onion and 3 garlic cloves while rice cooked on stove.  (3)  combined meat, rice, tomatoes, worcestershire in bowl.  Added generous shakes of "greek seasoning" and oregano (our taste) and crumbled feat to the mix before stuffing prebaked peppers.  Poured 1 can ready-prepared Tomato-Basil soup over peppers and baked at 350 for 30 minutes.  5+ stars with these changes for us.

text:
I doubled the rice (to 1 whole cup), used tomato sauce instead of tomato soup, and 1 small can tomatoes and green chilies (Rotel) instead of whole tomatoes due to personal preference. Then instead of baking I layered the stuffed peppers in my crockpot, poured the tomato sauce over them, and cooked on high for about an hour. The green chilies gave it a kick, and the crockpot meant I didn't have to heat up my house with the oven. I served with sour cream to tone it down for my husband, who doesn't like as much spice as I do.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6886093.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are the best stuffed peppers I've ever had.  Personally I'm not much of a meat and canned soup person, but based on the reviews I decided to try it.  The only difference was I added about a tablespoon of basil, oregano and cumin and 1 teaspoon of garlic powder.  The sauce was a tiny bit bland without these.  I was skeptical about the campbell's soup, but the tomato soup tastes excellent on these.  I can't tell that the topping is canned soup!  Will make again, but next time with veggie ground beef.
Update:  These turned out fantastic in the slow cooker.  Once the peppers were stuffed, I sprinkled the leftover meat mixture and extra tomato soup gravy.  I cooked in on low for 6 hours.  It turned out fantastic, and the peppers were beautifully roasted.  I just stuffed the peppers raw, so it eliminated pre-boiling them!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was about as good as it gets.  I made some tweaks, though. -2 tsp of minced garlic added with beef/onion to brown -Beef broth used in place of water (I went easy on the added salt because of this) -Arborio (risotto) rice.  A bit thicker than regular white rice, so it took an extra 5 minutes to cook. -Increased Worcestershire to 1 tbps -Added fresh basil and oregano at the same time as Arborio/rice -Sliced peppers length wise, as recommended here -Used Harry's Organic Creamy Tomato Basil Soup in place of condensed cream of tomato soup. (can be bought at Costco) -Kept 1/8 a cup of cheddar for topping right before placing in the oven -Set broiler on high for the last 3-4 minutes to lightly brown.  This recipe will become a staple for us in the future.  Thanks a lot for giving me the building blocks to start with.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I had an abundance of peppers and tomatoes from my garden & needed to find something to do with them. So I thought of stuffed peppers which I have not had since my grandmother made them 25 years ago. I'm not really a big fan of peppers or tomatoes but gave this a whirl. So Glad I did. OMG. So Good. I did listen to others comments and was sure to boil peppers first. I cooked the rice first in beef broth and set aside. I added 4 big cloves of garlic, paprika, ground pepper and fresh oregano and basil from my garden. Cooked that together with beef. I also put cheddar cheese in the bottom of each pepper. I used my own tomatoes which were boiled, skinned and de-seeded. I also topped them off with mozzerella cheese, only because I ran out of cheddar. I doubled the Worcestershire and only used one can of tomato soup. I also poured some of the sauce in the pepper, then filled them half way, added more sauce. Then I finished topping them, more sauce and cheese on top. My partner saw me putting in tomatoes and had a fit because he hates them. I told him to get out of the kitchen. Well he came back for seconds as did I. Two people that don't care for peppers or tomatoes loved them. So Good. Next time I will add more garlic, salt, pepper and fresh herbs for a bit more flavor.

text:
This was excellent and also a fairly healthy meal. My only change was by mistake but next time making might actually do the same way. I added what i thought was a can of diced tomatoes but ended up being crushed tomatoes. This made the beef/rice mixture a little more soupy (which we liked) and also didn't have the problem with the tomato soup not seeping down to the bottom of the pepper like one reviewer complained because it already had plenty moisture. Because of this i only needed to add one can of tomato soup on top the peppers. I served it over rice. Next time the only thing i may do different is add some garlic like others did.  All in all very good comfort food.

I have tried many different stuffed pepper recipes and I found I like this one the best!  I had never cooked the meat first, but when I used this recipe and did exactly as it said, the peppers weren't "mushy" when they were done.  I usually follow the recipe as written, but if I have it, I sometimes add some ground pork or even hot sausage to the hamburg.  I had always used spaghetti sauce and was leary of plain old tomato soup, but it works well.  When peppers are plentiful, I like to make a roaster full and freeze them.  They are wonderful for a day when there is no time to prepare a meal!  Thanks Suzanne!

I received this recipe via email yesterday and made the stuffed peppers last night.  I only made one change and that was to add quinoa instead of rice. I felt like 2 cans of tomato soup was too much - I would only use one next time.  This would also make a great stuffing for cabbage rolls.  Great recipe!

text:
I made this recipe tonight.  I gave the recipe 4 stars, but only because I made the following changes to the recipe.  I sautéed the onion, and beef with 1tbsp minced garlic.  I put in ½-cup water, one can tomato soup, 1tbsp beef bouillon, 1-cup rice, 1tbsp Worchester, 1tbsp of pre mixed Italian seasoning and 1 tbsp of basil.  For the diced tomatoes, I used Italian seasoned diced tomatoes.  I then let simmer for about 20 minutes stirring to avoid sticking.    My husband does not like cheese, so I divided the stuffing.  Some I did w/out the cheese, and a couple I did with.  Both tasted very good, and my husband said, “It’s a keeper”.  That is good for me!    Happy cooking!

Huge hit, even my dad who wont eat bell peppers (because they give him heartburn) ate all of his! text:
I made some changes, I used ground beef and sausage, I also used the creamy tomato soup in the sauce as well as the gravy on top ( Which it needed lots of) I added onion and garlic cooked seperately and rice also cooked alone and tasted the mix before placed inside the peppers. I made adjustments at this point, ( more salt pepper, a touch of red pepper flakes) If the mix tastes good go ahead. This is when I added the Creamy tomato soup. Both to the mix and on top of  the peppers. The important part to this recipe is to only boil the peppers 5 minutes or else it will break apart if overcooked. Also once the cheese is on , undo the foil for     10 minutes prior to eating it. Otherwise this recipe was awesome.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
A- This is a great recipe but like others, I had to tweak it to perfection. For one- I didn't use tomato soup. If you use a can of diced tomatoes- the juices in it, along with the chicken broth (which I used as a substitute for water), gave it enough broth. I did use some spaghetti sauce on top of the rice/beef mixture and then topped it off with cheddar cheese (grated). Also, when making the beef/rice mixture, I added oregano, a dash of red chili flakes and quite a bit of salt/pepper to flavour as if you do not, it is very bland and has almost a 'gamey' taste to it. Enjoy and this is one to keep in your recipe box!

text:
I cut the peppers in half lengthwise and filled each half.  I added more Worchestershire sauce than called for, three garlic cloves, and also added one small hot pepper chopped up.  I also put a slice of mozzarella cheese on top of each half and put back into the oven for five minutes to melt the cheese.  Be sure to boil the peppers in hot water for five minutes before you put the stuffing in or they will be to crunchy.  They are even better the next day!!!

text:
Great recipe - I followed it to a T with the exception of the tomato soup step - I spooned in about 1 tbsp of concentrate from the can into the bottom of each blanched pepper, topped it with 1/2 filling, spooned about another tbsp tomato soup concentrate, filled each pepper to the top with filling, another tbsp soup then the cheese. I didnt want to water down the flavour of the soup, and it was a hit! They freeze amazingly well...and I have tried the filling with both ground beef, turkey, sausage, or a combo of the three. Good stuff!!!

text:
I really liked this recipe; although I made a few tweaks. First off, I used green/red peppers because I think they give off a better flavor. Also, I used chicken broth for everything that called for water (since I used ground turkey). I also added a good bit of paprika, minced garlic and garlic powder to the mix while I was cooking it.  I used a whole can of broth instead of 1/2 a cup, because the rice took longer to tenderize and it kept getting dryer than I prefer. There is nothing worse than a dry stuffed pepper! They came out really great! I was cooking for a friend of mine, and she said they were the best stuffed peppers she ever had!

Display Name:
serenity8675

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/282535.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These peppers turned out great!  I would give it 5 starts, except I made some changes.  I didn't boil the peppers beforehand;  I just increased the time in the oven.  Used 1/2 cup of onions.  Cooked my rice in a rice cooker, mixed it with everything else and let it simmer for about 10 minutes to let the flavors mix.  I added cumin, red pepper flakes, salt, pepper, italian seasoning and extra Worcestershire sauce to the mixture.  Also used a can of diced tomatos with green chiles in them for an extra kick.  I followed other reviewers' advice and put sauce and cheese in the bottom of each pepper, added some of the mixture and then did another layer of sauce and cheese and then finished stuffing the pepper and topped with more cheese.  I used tomato sauce instead of tomato soup (don't care for the soup flavor).  Coated the bottom of the pan with a layer of tomato sauce to keep the bottoms of the peppers from burning.  Served over white rice.  Delicious; will definitely be making again!!

I substituted a can of diced tomatoes with chipotle peppers for the regular tomatoes....it added some zip, but it was not overwhelming. I didn't have any shredded cheese, but the dish was just as good without it. I definitely will be making this many, many times!

text:
Thanks for the recipe! I love bell pepper, but I just do not know how to incorporate it into many dishes. This recipe is so perfect. I followed the basic structure of the recipe with some adjustments based on reviews. I used ground chicken and added some paprika, cayenne, garlic powder, poultry seasoning, Italian seasoning, and doubled Worcestershire. I didn't have tomato soup, so I used tomato sauce diluted with chicken stock. I also topped the stuffed peppers with Monterey pepper jack cheese. It turned out great but I see how it could have been better cooked in tomato soup. I like how this recipe has infinite potential to cook with bell peppers. Thanks.

text:
This was delicious! I did make a few changes based on other reviews. I used a can of diced tomatoes instead of the whole tomatoes. I didn't bother boiling the peppers ahead of time. I also cooked the rice separately and then added it to the skillet at the end to warm it up and mix the flavors. I doubled the Worcestershire sauce and cheese amounts. I cut the peppers in half length-wise, laid them in a baking dish and stuffed them that way. I used tomato sauce rather than the soup and layered the sauce and beef/rice mixture when stuffing the peppers. I poured extra sauce and cheese over the peppers then baked for 40 minutes.

text:
I made some minor changes, and we loved it! First of all I was trying to use up some of the abundant peppers and tomatoes from my garden, so I didn't used canned tomatoes...just peeled some fresh and it tasted wonderful!  I also used ground turkey (97% fat free) and browned it with the onions and a couple cloves of garlic.  I cooked my rice prior to mixing it with the meat so that it wouldn't be crunchy - I grew up with crunchy stuffed peppers and never want to have that again!  Since everything was precooked prior to baking in the oven...I only found it necessary to use one can of condensed tomato soup and about 1/2 can of water. They were wonderful and my husband would like me to make these weekly!!!

These turned out fairly well in our house.  We have a large family and lots of peppers in our garden so I doubled the recipe and altered it a little according to other suggestions.  Since our peppers weren't real big I made them according to the recipe and cut them in half and laid them in a 9x13 pan. I have never made stuffed peppers before and was unsure of what to serve with it.  We opted for garlic cheese toast.  Good meal!  Thanks for the recipe.

text:
I only gave it four stars because I modified the recipe a bit I guess. I modify a lot of the recipes to our liking and add things that I think we would like. I used some of the other recommendations. I cooked the rice separately with chicken broth and onions. I sauteed onions, garlic, and minced mushrooms and added them to the cooked beef. I also used spicy spaghetti sauce in place of the tomato soup and mixed that into the beef mixture and also put some on top of the peppers. I loved the cheese mixed throughout the peppers. I cut my peppers in half lengthwise. I had never done that before and I really liked the way they came out. I also used half green and half red peppers. The reds are really delicious! The next time I make these I am going to boil them for a little longer maybe because they were still a bit crunchy.

text:
I've tried many stuffed green pepper recipes, but this is the best!
I'm a bit calorie/fat conscious and you an easily cut the calories (but not taste) by about 150 calories per green pepper by doing the following:
1) use 90% lean meat
2) use 98% fat free tomato soup (and use only 1 can)
3) use fat free cheddar cheese

text:
I love this recipe.  I use it all the time.  I do tweak ingredients a little bit to fit our tastes.  You definately have to precook the peppers or they take forever in the oven.  I added minced fresh garlic, 1 small can of mushrooms and garlic salt.  After the beef was brown, I just added all the remaining ingredients, except the cheese, to cook together.  I used tomato sauce instead of soup and used less water.  The rice cooks just fine in the tomato soup.  I add a layer of the mixture to the bottom of the baking pan to hold the peppers in place, add the stuffed peppers and sprinkle any remaining mixture in between the peppers.  I sprinkle the whole thing with cheese.  Great recipe and very easy.

text:
These were good but I made a few changes.  I used a whole med sized onion. Used diced tomatoes instead of whole and added about a quarter cup of mild salsa because some reviewers thought they were bland.  Also just used plain canned (hunts) tomato sauce on top as we don't buy condensed tomato soup so obviously we didn't have any on hand.  Topped with cheddar they came out very flavorful - not bland at all!  The salsa gave then a little bit of tang which was nice.  Thanks for the recipe will use again with some of these changes.  I might even break down a buy some soup to try on top.  I'm sure it would be good

These are great!  I had never made stuffed peppers before and I think I definitely picked the right recipe to start with.  I made a couple small alterations:  I sliced extra-large peppers long-wise instead of cutting the tops off smaller ones, I used provolone cheese instead of chedder, I used crushed tomatoes instead of whole, and I added a few dashes of hot sauce to the filling. I really like these I just can't follow a recipe to save my life so I switched it around a bit.  I used ground turkey instead of ground beef to start out with to save on fat.  I used one can of diced peeled tomatoes with roasted garlic.  I added garlic, fresh basil, fresh parsely, oregano, garlic, cumin, cayenne pepper and 4 tbls of worcestershire sauce, and added a can of corn.  I used minute rice as well and had no problems.  I also switched it to the kraft cheddar melt cheese and used 1/2 cup onion.  I used healthy choice tomato soup to make it a bit healthier.  A huge hit and will make again only with some black beans in it as well next time.

text:
I was looking for a basic stuffed bell pepper recipe yesterday...and I found this one.  I made some alterations (okay, a lot of alterations) and it turned out great!!  

Here's what I did:  

- chorizo sausage (not ground beef)
- minced celery (1)
- minced carrot (1)
- minced garlic (4 cloves)
- 1.5 tablespoons of Worcestershire sauce
- fresh herbs (parsley, basil)
- shredded Jack, mozzarella and chedder cheese.  

I also substituted the green peppers for yellow and red peppers (adds a nice sweetness!)

The peppers had so much flavor--I swear if you try the recipes with my alterations, you'll love 'em!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Having a bumper crop of green peppers this season, I decided to find a recipe for stuffed green peppers. I used 8 small green peppers, 1 quart of home canned tomatoes, seasoned the ground beef with grill mates seasoning for a little kick along with browning it with the onion, added 1 cup Fat Free Cheddar Cheese.  I also added 1/4 cup reg. parmesan cheese. I only used 1 can of tomato soup with a little water for the gravy part, was just enough.  It took alot longer than 15 minutes to cook the rice, so I cooked it until it was tender, about 25 minutes.  Baked in 350 degree oven for 45 minutes, done to perfection! Using FF cheese cut the calories down, and for WeightWatchers, it ended up being 4 points per pepper. I will be making these AGAIN! Thanks for the great recipe!!

text:
This was very good and very different.  I usually make stuffed peppers Italian style, but I liked this one.  I added a little extra onion and 2 cloves crushed garlic and some oregano.  I upped the rice to 1 cup and the water to 2 cups (otherwise the mixture kept drying out).  I also added in the juice from the tomatoes.  It took my rice mixture almost 30 minutes to become tender.  And since you are only baking the peppers for 30 minutes, you really need to make sure the rice is DONE.  My husband really liked these as well.  Thanks.

text:
This was a wonderful meal.  I used red peppers - less acidity for dh, and so much better.  I skipped the worcestershire sauce,tomato soup, and water.  Instead, when it says to add the tomatoes, add Pastene Kitchen Ready (ground, peeled tomatoes - the whole can) with a little italian seasonings.  It makes a mini marinara that you can pour over the peppers.  Delicious.

text:
I was a little nervous about venturing out on something so different - but to tell you the truth, these were a breeze to make and really delicious.   I only could find 4 decent medium sized peppers so I halved them and stuffed them beyond all get out, giving me 8 fat peppers.  I only used 1 can of soup, which was more than enough.  I also mixed in 1/2 a small can of Redpack "Hot n Spicy" tomato sauce which added the perfect amount of heat!  I will DEFINTELY make these again without a doubt!!!

text:
YUMMMMMM!!! I made this for picky Korean in-laws, and it was a huge hit; even though they aren't big on cheese, they loved it!
Only recommendation is to add more than 1/2C water; I found it took a while for the rice to become tender, it soaks up the water fast and everything tends to scorch. This is truly delicious! Definitely worth trying, and will make it again!

text:
Good and easy!   
I've made this recipe 2 times because my husband LOVES it!  It is  a quick and easy meal and freezes well.  The recipe says it makes six peppers but keep in mind what size peppers you are using.   The first time I made it  I got four.  The 2nd time I got 5.  To get six you need to have peppers on the smaller side.  I did make one change out of laziness.  Instead of the tomato soup, I just put ketsup on top and it was very good.  This is a KEEPER!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I hate to do such a low rating, But I found this recipe (to my family’s taste) very bland. The stuffing was mushy. I was following the instructions ,since this was the first time I was making this, but I kept thinking to myself,”I don’t know about this?!” 
I am going to use this as a blue print and maybe do half hamburger and half sausage. Season to your taste cook, drain. Sauté onions , garlic with other veggies and herbs of your choice . Cook rice separately! NO cheddar cheese! Mix all this together and add like 1/2 cup of fresh mozzarella or Parmesan. Top with a mixture of Italian bread crumbs mixed with a little Parmesan in the peppers.  No mush. I think the problem was just too much cheddar cheese mixed in ruined the whole recipe. I am so sorry to the chef. But no.

Display Name:
Connie Dewing

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6591317.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I’ve tried a few versions. This is the one that I like because of the tomato soup, it changes the flavor from just tomato sauce, like every other recipe out there that I’ve tried. 
Soooooo here’s my modifications. I added oregano and basil and mix one can of soup with one can of water then mix that in with the rice/meat mix. Stuff it into pepper top with cheese and bake. 
I tried this time not salting the peppers directly and family all commented on it wasn’t the same. 
So while I thought it was too much salt, the peppers need it (IMO) 
This really did hit the mark of what I wanted from a stuffed green pepper, and it’s good for throwing in leftover veg from the fridge too. To make it a bit more healthy :)

I made this for my husband and mother and they both enjoyed it. I did add some bacon to the ground beef mix, as well as some Italian seasoning, and added some extra cheese to the top for the last few minutes of baking. I think if I make it again, I’ll try slicing the peppers in half before stuffing and baking them, since they cut them in half to eat them anyway. But it was a pretty simple recipe, and a little faster to cook  than some of the others I’d seen.

text:
Delicious!  Per other reviews I cut the peppers in half, sprinkled a little cheese in the peppers before filling them, added basil, oregano and Italian seasoning, used bouillon instead of water to thin the tomato soup.  I think the cheddar cheese added to the meat mix at the end is what really brings this recipe together and makes the meat filling so delicious.  Also I used Uncle Ben's microwave packet of rice (super easy microwave 90 seconds) so it was fully cooked before I added it to the meat mixture.

text:
Made these as directed for the most part. I used a whole small onion because, why not? And I only used one can of soup. I took someone’s suggestion and put a scoop of filling in each pepper followed by a spoonful of the soup. Then I filled the peppers up the rest of the way and topped with the remaining soup. I also added more cheese on the top after the stated cooking time and then popped them back in the oven uncovered just long enough for the cheese to melt. They were fabulous. Even my picky daughter loved the filling, although she wouldn’t eat the cooked pepper. This is a new family favorite!

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Awesome base recipe. I did modify though - I first sautéed the onions and minced garlic, then added rice and cooked for a couple of minutes. Mixed in one can of diced, fire-roasted tomatoes and then covered that with chicken stock. I also added way more Worcestershire sauce, like a tablespoon or two. I let it come to a boil, then simmered for 15 minutes until rice was tender. I browned the meat (turkey instead of beef) and added the rice combination. I sliced the peppers lengthwise before stuffing, and cooked them on the pellet grill for 15 minutes, with just cheese, no tomato soup. DELICIOUS!! Can't wait to make it again!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I had a nagging feeling that I should have cooked the rice first, but I decided to follow the directions. Alas, when I sat down to take a bite, the rice was still hard. I had to add some water to the bottom of the dish with the peppers, cover it, and steam it for another 15 minutes for the rice to soften sufficiently. So my advice is to cook the rice first, and then mix it in with the rest of the filling. I used a ground meat substitute from Trader Joe's to make this vegetarian, and it worked just fine. :)

text:
These are very similar to the ones my mom made me as a kid. However, I highly recommend adding garlic to the beef mixture, along with onion powder, garlic powder and some Italian seasoning. Also, I would pre-cook the rice before adding it in. For those that used tomato sauce, that's great, but a totally different recipe. This is for people who use tomato soup instead. It irritates me when people say they made this but they actually made a totally different recipe instead.

text:
First time I made it following the directions exactly ... delicious! Five stars. Family loved it. Second time, I made some adjustments that took it over the top. First I sauted the onion and a couple cloves of garlic in butter. I pre-cooked the rice. Then I added it all to cooked Italian Sausage and added a cup of pasta sauce to the filling (along with all the other ingredients). I also cut the bell peppers long ways and microwaved them upside down with a little water in the baking dish prior to filling them (way easier than using a separate pot and boiling water). The family RAVED.

text:
I think this is a great foundation recipe to get cooking times and ingredient ratios from. I do modify it for my own taste. My family likes a little bite in the green peppers, so I don't boil them.  I only use 3-4 peppers for the recipe, and I cut them in half to fill them. I use chunky spaghetti sauce instead of tomato sauce, and saute onions and garlic into the beef before I mix the filling together. I also sometimes add a can of diced tomatoes, a Serrano pepper, or seasoning into the rice for extra flavor.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the same recipe i have been using for YEARS! Many reviewers change the recipe so it is unrecognizable. As an inventive cook,  I like to change up recipes using what I have on hand or what I am in the mood for. I won't bore you with all my various changes I make, but, I WILL share a timesaving tip. I cut the peppers lengthwise. Once I have assembled the stuffing, I place the uncooked peppers cut side down on top of the stuffing in a large skillet and cover. The peppers cook perfectly while the stuffing cooking. Assemble the peppers with stuffing in a baking pan and finish them up in the oven.  Np parboiling, no microwave and one less dish to wash! Yum!

text:
This turned out great! I did not change much. I used half the beef because I only had 3 peppers, but last minute decided to make the full recipe for the filling because my peppers were humongous. In the end that was wise, it made the perfect amount. I added about 2tbsp of tomato paste to the soup and did not add water, and followed another user’s suggestion to spoon in some soup halfway after filling the peppers. I saved a bit of cheese for the top but did not increase the overall amount of cheese. This was a yummy and simple recipe and even my picky children gobbled it up.

text:
Yes, I made a couple of changes.  This recipe is very close to the one which I've been using since I first got married.  I add a small can of (drained) corn, but I don't add in the 2 cans of tomato soup (in order to eliminate the sodium, and the extra calories).  When the peppers are almost done, I slide them out of the oven, and top each pepper with a generous squirt of ketchup, and then top them w/cheese....and back into the oven they go for a couple of more minute, until the cheese is nicely melted.

text:
Instead of adding water, I added milk  to give it a creamier taste. Half and  half or whipping cream gives the sauce much more flavor.  Half-and-half or whipping cream can also be used with a small pinch of sugar for added flavor.  I also substituted red peppers for the green because the green peppers give the dish too strong a flavor.  The red peppers half a much milder taste and with the cream/milk made the dish a winner.

Display Name:
Elizabeth Baxter Hardin Duckwo
isPro:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wow, this dish has been around since my childhood and I'm 76.
During WWII we did't always have a lot of choices and this dish was a family favorite for leftovers, rarely did my mother ever fix this from exactly the ingredients given here, sometimes it was rice, sometimes leftover spaghetti but she always used ground beef which even during that time was better than the ground beef available today.  She always used red or yellow peppers because that's what she had in her garden.  She always topped her peppers with Parmesan cheese, we didn't use cheese as much as we do today, at least not in the same ways we do now.  She topped her peppers with a can of tomato sauce.
She used garlic and herbs according to her taste, it always changed according to availability because it was always out of the garden or what was at the store.

text:
This recipe allows a lot of opportunity to individualize as many reviewer‘s have said. One reviewer said they cut the peppers in half lengthwise. I went one step further and cut them in quarters length wise and put them at the bottom of a casserole dish with the filling on top. This way the serving size is more individualized than just one pepper per person. The children eat less and the grown-up men and teenage boys eat lots more.

text:
I love this and I made it a number of times.  My personal changes were to change up half of the beef for ground sausage and to use tomato sauce for half of the topping sauce.  Tomato soup is so sweet it was overwhelming.  I also like to add a little seasoning to the sauce - cayenne, onion powder, garlic power, regular pepper, but that's my personal preference.  If you like it traditional style, stick with the soup!  Still will make again, especially when we have fresh peppers in the garden!

userID:
5400473
Display Name:
AuntieM
isPro:
False
followersCount:
2

madeRecipesCount:
21
favoritesCount:
575
recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674145.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My mother always added a can of corn to the mixture. When tomatoes and corn are in season I use fresh. Dice tomatoes over a bowl to keep the juices but remove seeds.  Usually one or two ears of sweet corn will yield enough to equal a 10 oz can of corn. I prefer the tomato soup over sauce as others suggest. I also top them off with buttered bread cubes to  give it a crunch. Just make some bread cubes from whatever bread you have on hand make as much as you like. I tend to use 4 slices per 6 whole"topped" peppers . If you are slicing your peppers in half you may need to double this according to your desires. 

After cubing bread, place a stick of butter in a frying pan and once melted toss in cubes and fry until toasted and golden. Then place on top of peppers evenly before pacing in oven.
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a tasty meal that I want to make again. I followed some suggestions from other reviewers as well. I only used one green pepper which I split in half and microwaved cut side down for 3 minutes. That eliminated the boiling, and I would cut that time down to 2  1/2 minutes. I cooked the rice first before adding it to the meat mixture. I also added minced garlic to the ground beef.  Since the rice was cooked, I only simmered the meat mixture and rice for about 5 minutes, adding a little bouillon instead of water before putting it in the peppers. I  covered them with shredded cheese.  I didn't have tomato soup so I used picante sauce. I made extra rice and meat mixture, which I put in with the peppers in the oven for 30 minutes at 350.  Next time I would add more cheese and sauce.

aing

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614254.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The filling in this recipe lends itself to all kinds of variations.  This is a good basic recipe.  I cut the recipe in half, as I only had 3 peppers.  I'm glad the peppers were blanched, and the ingredients precooked, as that made the baking time necessary only to warm all of the peppers  to the right temperature to sit down and eat to a hot, but not too hot, supper.  I did not salt the peppers after blanching, as there is a low salt diet family member.  We salt the food on our plates instead.  I added 1 C freshly cooked rice (cuts down on prep time), and a pint of home canned whole tomatoes.  Because the tomatoes were home canned, I did not need to add the 1/2 c of water, and I added the juice from the canned tomatoes to the bottom of the dish under the peppers.

text:
Because i adjusted few things I could not star it higher then 3, I used this as a base recipe and changed things accordingly to our family liking etc.  I used the tops of the peppers (cut off the stems) as a "hat" :) for the peppers, I cooked rice in a separate dish as I wanted to have extra rice for us to have on the side, and it speeded up the overall cooking of the peppers too ...i added garlic and sauteed with onion when meat was almost done, and added a taco seasoning for more taste ...i did not add worchester sauce or the tomato soup- i only used the can of cut tomatos- I only made 4 peppers and the rest of the mixed meat/rice /tomatos I put on the bottom on my dish where i put the peppers- and did all on the top stove .... finished with some mozzarella pieces ( photos posted)

text:
If you have time to cook or slow cooker, I recommend a different approach. It is rather flavorless, plus I agree with some other reviewers for prep. Why I didn't like this recipe:  not much taste, meat mixture like crumbles, save oven time, but not prep. In short, my old recipe calls for uncooked meat, par boiled rice, a little bacon, egg, tomatoes, onion, some chopped green pepper. I usually cook onion, green pepper, then add to rest with salt, pepper, and garlic powder. Obviously cooking time extended to cook raw peppers and raw meat. Sauce I use paste or sauce with added garlic powder, salt, pepper, sugar, basil and water if I used paste. Always serve with mashed potatoes and make sure to make extra sauce for them!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3604704.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious!  Here's how I made them: browned the beef with the onion and maybe  1 1/2 teaspoon of jarred minced garlic.  I used a can of diced tomatoes with Italian seasonings, and used the entire can without draining.  I also substituted chicken broth for the water.  I also used lightly less rice.  For the peppers, I used 1 1/2 green (used a leftover half green), 1 red, 1 orange and 1 yellow.  When I constructed the peppers, I sprinkled salt at the bottom, put shredded cheese, then meat mixture, then spooned tomato sauce, then added more meat mixture and finally topped with more cheese.  Baked for 25 minutes and they were perfect!!  They were slightly over filled, so another half pepper would have been perfect (i.e., need to use 5 altogether).

text:
This was a good recipe. I substituted ground turkey for the hamburger because we are watching our fat intake. I also used a green pepper, a red, an orange and a yellow instead of all green and I did not par-boil them first. I sliced them long-ways in half, poured the soup base on the bottom of the dish, put the peppers in, salt & peppered them, stuffed and baked. I think next time I won't add the tomato soup base, we didn't like the taste with that, but the peppers and meat mixture was great! Thanks!

Everyone loves when I make this recipe.  I make it at home probably twice a month and my family loves it. When you have to help out another family who is sick or grieving this is a great thing to bring because it is easy, fast, travels well and everyone loves it. text:
I also cooked raw rice separately to make sure they were fully cooked. I hate crunchy rice.   It is very important to Par-Boil a full 5 minutes if you stuff the whole pepper.  I did not like the idea of Tomato Soup so I used about a cup or more of canned crushed tomatoes in bottom of dish and it was a great sauce to add to peppers after cooking.  Yes, add some sauteed onion and minced garlic!  These are great and can be refrigerated and heated in micro later.  I make 6, eat 2 and devour the others later.  Have not tried freezing but will.

text:
I thought this was great, and the cheddar cheese adds terrific flavor and it smells wonderful while it's cooking. The only thing I changed really was using a can of already diced tomatoes instead of the whole tomatoes. This threw the liquid to rice ratio off a little and the peppers were a bit soupy. So I would say to adjust this just add a bit more rice or try to drain off a little bit of the liquid if you use pre-diced tomatoes. I've already made this twice! Love this recipe!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4248911.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe for dinner last night. I did not have any condensed tomato soup, but did have an extra can of diced tomatoes. I boiled a can of diced tomatoes with 1 oz. diced onion, 0.5 oz. carrots, 0.5 oz. of celery, water and a clove of garlic, plus italian seasoning, salt, and pepper. Once all vegetables were tender, I blended this smooth. I used half a pound of breakfast sausage (because I needed to get rid of it) and a half pound of ground beef. I did boil the peppers as directed, then salted them inside lightly and added about a tablespoon of cheese after boiling. Meat and onions plus salt and pepper were cooked together and drained. Then, I added the salt and pepper, diced tomatoes, half the soup, rice, meat/onions, Worcestershire, 1 Tbsp Italian seasoning, a spoon of minced garlic, a little extra oregano and basil, and water to the pan and simmered until rice was tender. Spooned this immediately into peppers. Topped them with the rest of the soup and cheese. Baked them at 350F for 25 minutes and they were PERFECT! Will definitely make again.

Modified  recipe by using  1 cup rice , 1 cup water, 28 oz petite diced tomatoes,  Dale  steak sauce, chicken bouilleon,1 whole onion, pizza  seasoning, cut up bell pepper  lids and added to meat mixture, used 8 bell peppers. userID:

Display Name:
michigoose 
isPro:

followersCount:

favoritesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614247.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love these peppers. In fact, this is the only way that cooked green peppers will even make it on to my plate. I have made them several times and have tried some of the variations that other reviewers have shared. But, they are little changes, like adding some sauce mid-way through stuffing the peppers, or cutting the peppers lengthwise instead of  topping them, or baking them a little longer for temperature. 

I prefer them upright, as in the recipe. I'm very picky at the pepper bin at the grocery store and am sure to select only fruits with four even lobes so that they won't fall over in the cooking dish.  And I do add some sauce halfway through stuffing.

But, ingredients-wise, I wouldn't change a thing. The tomato soup is genius. They are just the right amount of sweet and savory. I would eat these a lot more often if I didn't think my husband would get bored.

userID:

Display Name:
AngieBK
isPro:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3882726.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this recipe regularly over the last 3 years. I  have tried many suggestions listed from reviewers and some of my own experiments to see if I could improve on an already wonderful base recipe.  I think I've found the best combination to make a very savory dish.  I added 2 tsp of minced garlic to the meat and onion during cooking.  I increased the Worcestershire Sauce to 3 tsp.  I doubled the rice and cooked it separately adding 1 tsp Oregano, 1 bay leaf, and 1 beef bouillon cube.  The original recipe seemed to be short on stuffing, so the added rice really bulked it up.  Instead of tomato soup (which is good also), I tried both Spaghetti sauce and tomato sauce with added Oregano and garlic, and both were fantastic.  I like putting a little sauce inside the pepper before adding the stuffing to meld that flavors through the mixture.  I like to serve it with cornbread, the sweet and savory go so well together.

text:
I'm giving this recipe four stars because I thought it was really good. I followed the instructions to a T but, realized that it needed a little help. I prefer more rice than it called for so, I made a second half cup of rice on the side and added it to the filling once everything was ready to go. Also, the uncooked rice wasn't tender after simmering for 15 minutes. I added a bit more water and simmered it for another 5 minutes. The flavor was great! I wouldn't add anything as far as spices or flavors go. Thanks for the share! I'll definitely make this again.

userID:

Display Name:
bloodred_lips15

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674158.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Love this recipe!! It is a big one in our house. Only gave it 4 stars because had to make some changes after reading some reviews. I cut the tops off the peppers and boil them for 3-4 minutes, after that I put some seasoning and cheese at the bottom of the peppers. While browning the meat I add a lot of basil, oregano,  italian seasoning and galic salt. After I drain the meat (which you don't really have to do cause it isn't that greasy depending on the percentage you use) I will add more seasoning while it simmers. I buy the canned diced tomatoes with basil,garlic and oregano already in them. After simmering, ill sometimes add a few dashes of Frank's red hot to spice it up a bit. I add the cheese while it is still warm so its gooey and melted. Only one can of soup is really needed, and sometimes I water it down and other times I don't.  Not a huge fan of tomato soup so I really only use half the can when its watered down. 
This really is a awesome recipe, just can come out a bit bland and needs a little hit :)

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Because my boys are always bringing friends home to eat, I've had to stretch a recipe quite often.  Just add a can of corn to your filling, and a little extra Worcestershire sauce.  I've found over the years that when it is hot and I don't want to turn the oven on, I cut my peppers in half length wise, place them cut side down in a microwaveable casserole, with just a tiny bit of water.  Microwave for about 2 minutes, covered, turn them over, fill with mixture, top with sauce and cheese, and cook in microwave for about 10 minutes.  Quick and delicious.

text:
I liked the idea of  peppers stuffed with"loose" meat rather than a meatloaf type filliing and so will give these a try soon.  So, my ratinig is based on the concept, not experience.  I plan to make the following changes:  red peppers instead of green, diced tomatoes, addition of garlic, addition of red pepper flakes, topping with Old Fashioned Tomato Rice Soup and 1/2 cup of cream, (which is what I have used for "meatloaf" stuffed pepper.  The sweetness of this soup combined with the cream is the perfect sauce to accompany the baked peppers.

text:
I don't like green bell peppers...so I always use red/yellow/orange variety. It really adds the perfect sweetness to stuffed peppers. We are eating healthy, so we used ground turkey instead of ground beef and quinoa instead of rice.  I also added a couple links of Sweet Italian Turkey Sausage for flavor because I usually gook with Italian sausage rather than ground beef when I'm not eating healthy.  ;-)  Also...I doubled the Worcestershire and added garlic and Italian seasoning to the meat mixture.  I always put balsamic into my tomato sauce before I poured it over the peppers.  I made this in the slow-cooker and therefore did not cook the meat or peppers before hand.  Perhaps I should just create a new recipe...stay tuned...

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
DELICIOUS!!!! My German-Dutch soul is so happy with this recipe. I only changed three things to this recipe. I added a Tbsp of Burgandy cooking wine (a staple to most of my red meat and tomato base dishes) & a liberal (to taste) sprinkling of garlic powder to my rice/meat mixture. I also used a pre-mixed 1# meatloaf mixture as a sub for ground beef. My rice was a half cup of brown rice and an add'l handful of Arborio rice halfway through the rice cook time. My frugal heart couldn't bear to throw out the entire tops of the green peppers, so I carefully sliced the usable pepper on the "lids" dicing them and adding them into the stuffing when I added the arborio rice. This will be a permanent addition to our favorite meals in this household. Thank you for sharing your recipe with us all :)

text:
These were great! The only thing I'd say is to boil/cook the rice before it is added to the meat mixture. Unless I missed something, it seems above to add uncooked rice to mixture and once tender then move to next step. I did that and the end result was the rice was not cooked. Other than that, it was delicious and I will cook the rice alone next time first! Thank you for great recipe! & used 2 cans of tomatoes/green chiles instead of the others.I am terrible with rice so I cook my rice in a rice cooker and add it to the pot to simmer covered for a few mins. So I omit the water and just cook my rice in rice cooker.

text:
I am giving this recipe five stars when made with some adjustments and additions. First, I used over one pound of beef and only five peppers and had the perfect amount of filling. I added garlic as it was glaringly missing. I also put in some spices to the beef to kick it up (red pepper flakes, cumin). When I added in the cheese at the end I also threw in some sour cream to make the mix slightly creamier. After I poured the tomato sauce on top of the filled peppers I put more cheese on top and broiled the dish after baking to get a nice browned topping. They came out spicy and delicious! Peppers were cooked perfectly.

By mistake I added the tomato soup into the beef mixture with the tomato's.  This helped keep the beef mixture moist and it added wonderful flavor to the mixture.  I left a little to drizzle over the bell peppers for added flavor. Then towards the last five minutes I top the peppers with the cheese and allow it to melt. Overall the bell peppers are delicious.

I will go back to my recipe using raw peppers and not cooking the mixture, it's much faster and easier.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674163.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this for the boyfriend and it has become one of our favorite things to eat.  Keep in mind, I never was a fan of bell peppers until this recipe.  Some tips: I prefer using red, yellow, and orange bell peppers; they give a sweeter taste.  Also, when browning the meat, I added some Italian seasoning, tripled the Worcestershire sauce, and added minced garlic. (or else the meat will be bland.) Cook the rice beforehand. With the tomato soup, skip adding water; it'll make it too runny.  Fill in the peppers halfway with the beef mixture. Add a bit of tomato sauce and fill up the rest with beef mixture and top with tomato sauce again. This will allow the soup to seep to the bottom and give more flavor. Using diced canned tomatoes saves time on chopping.

Just used this recipe as my first try at cooking stuffed peppers and it was amazing! Did make some adjustments according to other users reviews - tripled the Worcestershire sauce, added oregano, a few pinches of cayenne for a little kick, minced garlic and used Uncle Ben's boil in a bag rice (which I think is always good!) also used 1.35lbs of ground beef with about 1&1/2 cups of the rice, and purchased pre-diced tomatoes. Paired the dish with corn, garlic bread and a caprese salad - delicious!!! My boyfriend was raving and even better - we have leftovers for tomorrow! This is a must make and will repeat!

text:
I give this recipe 4 stars since, like many others, I found that the rice does not cook sufficiently in 15 minutes. So I doubled the amount of water and Worcestershire and cooked about 20-25 minutes making sure the rice was done.  Also, after stuffing,  I cooked it about 40 minutes; 25 covered then 15 uncovered. All in all, I love this recipe; it tastes great!  Oh yeah, I also half my peppers in order to have leftovers...even better left over and reheated.

text:
I love this recipe, i usally make taco suffed peppers, but i have to say these were alot better. I did make a few changes, only added 1 can of tomato soup with equal parts water, add garlic powder, oregano, basil, italian seasoning, little extra worcestershire sauce, jalepenos and black beans. And instead of using can tomatos i used fresh tomatoes from the garden about 4, I blended 3 and diced the other. I also used jasmine rice. served with tortilla chips or homemade tortilla chip which ever u perfer.

text:
Delicious!  I was using very small bell peppers from my garden, so I used 14 instead of 6, and the stuffing amount worked out perfectly.  I also used chopped roma tomatoes from my garden in place of canned, and I used Campbell's "Harvest Orange" condensed tomato soup.  That gave it beautiful color and a great flavor.  This took me quite a bit longer than estimated in the recipe- a little over 2 hours until dinner was ready, but that wasn't too surprising given the extra prep of smaller peppers, the fresh tomatoes, and the fact that I'm just not a very fast cook.  When I have the time, the result was well worth the effort!

Display Name:
Shari Violette Scheib
isPro:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5361312.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are the most delicious stuffed bell peppers I have ever had.  I took the advise of some of the other reviewers and used a pasta sauce in place of the soup; canned diced tomatoes with green chilies; pre-cooked brown rice in beef broth; added more Worcestershire sauce, onion, 4 cloves fresh garlic minced, and used 1-1/2 lbs. gr. beef (that's what I had); used jack cheese (that's what I had); greased the baking dish with shortening and didn't add liquid.  I also cut the peppers (red, yellow, orange and green) lengthwise, seeded them, and put 3 halves staggered on a microwave safe plate, then microwaved them for 4 minutes before stuffing.  I put a small slice of cheese inside the peppers before stuffing them and drizzled ketchup on top then put another slice of cheese on top before baking.  Everyone loved them.  Thank you Suzanne and thanks to the other reviews for their suggestions too!  This will be my go-to pepper recipe.  This filling stuffed 9 whole peppers.

Great recipe, will surely be making these again.

userID:
5454151
Display Name:
Jennie

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677174.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My husband and I have made this recipe twice and it's delicious!  However, we did make some large modifications including the following substitutions: red bell peppers for green peppers (I know, the recipe has "green pepper" in the title but the red are much tastier!), chicken chorizo for ground beef (about 1/4 pound per person), pre-seasoned diced canned tomatoes for the whole tomatoes, fresh tomato soup/bisque instead of the condensed tomato soup (no need to water down, and as another reviewer suggested, spoon it in between the filling layers).  We found that brown rice won't cook in the 15 minutes allotted, so during take 2 we cooked the brown rice separately in chicken broth for about 35 minutes (10 minutes less than suggested on the instructions), then added it when called for.  Because the rice was already at a softened state, we just simmered the mix for a few minutes to get the flavors to blend.  We added a bit more cheese than called for, mixing about half of it to the filling just before spooning it into the pepper.  The remaining cheese was placed on the top.  Finally, we added a minced jalepeno.  There were a lot of changes, but the end result was PERFECT!
Review:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Really enjoyed this recipe but changed a few of the ingredients and it added a little 'umph' that some reviews said it was needing. I used a tube of Jimmy Dean sausage instead of the ground beef. It gave it a little extra flavor. Once the sausage was browned I set it aside to drain and cooked the onions alone. After the onions were translucent I added the sausage back and continued to follow the directions. I used 14 oz. of fresh chopped tomatoes as well (instead of the canned). When the rice/sausage mixture was ready I put it in a mixing bowl and added 1/3 cup of canned rice, one half cup of shredded cheddar cheese, 5 dashes of Tobasco sauce and about 1/4 cup of freshly chopped cilantro.  I nixed the can of condensed tomato soup at the end I didn't think the mixture needed it. I baked it at 350 for 25 minutes and it was amazing! My husband and I will definitely eat it that way again! (note: boiling the peppers first is a MUST!)

I followed a few of the suggestions of the other reviewers and added 2 chopped chipotle peppers, oregano and a tsp. low-sodium taco seasoning to the tomato mixture. I also pre-cooked the rice in beef broth, added garlic to the sauteing onions and added corn, peas and carrots for some extra veggies. I mixed in sharp-cheddar and topped with a slice of monterey jack cheese. Hubby says he'd eat them again and he's a meat and potatoes kind of guy. I gave it a 4 as I think it would have been a bit bland without the other additions. Thanks for the recipe!

A good recipe but i added  a few things and replaced the tomato soup with a 50/50 mixture of salsa and pasta sauce.

country:
None
text:
I really enjoyed this recipe, even though I am not a huge fun of green peppers. I followed another reviewer's suggestion and filled the pepper halfway with the meat mixture and then covered the mixture with tomato soup, then added more meat and again covered with the soup. I believe this really helped the mixture remain moist and added more flavor. Also, I added a lot of italian seasoning to the tomato soup and free pressed garlic to the meat mixture. The only problem that I had was that the peppers fell apart after boiling. We had to hold them together with aluminum foil when putting them in to bake.

text:
Great recipe.  Added garlic and dried oregono to the ground beef as well as a pinch of cayanne for some kick.  The tomatos were diced (just easier) and I added basil to it.  I cooked rice seperately in the rice cooker (since it always turns out perfect that way).  I boiled the bell peppers for a bit longer and I'm glad I did.  They were perfect for eating with a fork.  Overall this is a great recipe to start but would suggest you play with it and make it your own.  My boyfriend LOVED this one!

userID:
4528048
Display Name:
r west
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
10
favoritesCount:
54
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674136.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Really good!  But it is hard for me to follow a recipe without giving my little twist on it.  I read alot of the reviews and tried my own.  I cut the peppers in half, boiled for a couple minutes, and set them aside to drain and sprinkled salt and pepper on them.  I browned and seasoned my ground meat, added garlic and onions, parsley, basil, oregano, hunt's seasoned diced tomatoes, worcestershire, and some ketsup.  Then added my rice, but added a little more then the recipe called for and added a little more water too.  (You can use the water you boiled your peppers in to give a little more flavor).  Dropped a little beef base in with it to soak up in the rice.  Brought to a boil.  Covered and cooked for 15 min.  DO NOT take the lid off during this time!  When done, push of fire and set aside still with lid on.  Then instead of only putting only chedder, I mostly put sliced cheese with a little chedder.  Stuffed peppers.  Warmed 1 can tomatoe soup and a V8 and seasoned sauce.  Put extra rice and meat mixture between peppers in dish. Topped with sauce and grated cheese and cooked.  EXCELLENT!
Review:

5

text:
YUMMY!!  I followed some other review's suggestions. 1) I used ground turkey, and seasoned with Italian seasoning, while browning.  2) I used a can of diced tomatoes. 3)  I added cheese (just a enough to cover the bottom) to bottom of peppers. 4) Filled half of pepper with beef mixture and then added a spoonful of the tomato soup( which I spiked with a dask of balsamic vinegar, 1Tbsp Italian dressing and 2 Tbsp, water~I spotted most of these measurements) then the beef mixture and topped of with the tomato soup.  Very moist!  Will make this again and again.  Thanks to all, for your input, makes a real difference..:)

Me and my husband loved these! I only made a couple of changes, intsead of cooking the rice mixture in water, i used beef stock and I think I used almost a cup because the rice wasn't cooking all the way, did add garlic, oregano and about half a packet of spaghetti seasoning. The tomato soup gives it a different flavor than what I'm used to in stuffed peppers, a little sweeter, but it was still good. This reciepe is going in my box to make again. The husband barely breathed while eating them!

Great recipe! This is a great crowd pleasing recipe. It is one of my favorites now. Thank you.

city:

country:
None
text:
OK-I strayed from this recipe and created my own , I guess. I don't like when people do it, but here it goes.  Reading other recipes, I decided to halve the peppers and roast them at 350 for 20 minutes. In the meantime, I cheated, pressed for time used a bag of microwave Uncle Bens jasmine rice (90 seconds)and sauteed garlic & onion in Olive oil. Then added the rice, some browned ground beef, some tomatoe sauce I had, chopped jalepenos, chopped cherry peppers and the like. Filled the pepper shells added cheese and put it in the oven for 5 more minutes. Nice firm peppers but fork cut perfect! Baking them first assures they will not get too soft as ingredients are already cooked.

text:
I'm giving it a 4 because I changed it so much, but the basic steps are the same. First, no tomato soup. It has too much sodium, and two cans of diced tomatoes with all the juice will make the peppers plenty fresh and juicy. I also chopped up the tops of the peppers and added them in with the onions. I melted a big handful of cheese into the tomato, meat (I used veggie meat- delicious!) mixture and topped them with cheese. As for spices, I used lots of garlic, Italian seasoning, and even some soy sauce. Let me tell you, they were freaking wonderful!

text:
Pretty good.  I cooked the beef with a TBSP of chopped garlic and the onions, then added 1/2 tsp of Basil, 2 tsp of Oregano, and 1 tsp Italian Seasoning.  I also doubled the Wors. sauce, though it tasted like it could use more.  I only used one can of tomato sauce and mixed it in the rice mixture while it was cooking.  The peppers do need some sauce on top though or the beef will get crispy and overdone.  Delicious.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was delicious! I did make a few changes based on other reviews. I used a can of diced tomatoes instead of the whole tomatoes.  I didn't bother boiling the peppers ahead of time.  I also cooked the rice separately and then added it to the skillet at the end to warm it up and mix the flavors.  I doubled the Worcestershire sauce and cheese amounts. I cut the peppers in half length-wise, laid them in a baking dish and stuffed them that way.  I used tomato sauce rather than the soup and layered the sauce and beef/rice mixture when stuffing the peppers.  I poured extra sauce and cheese over the peppers then baked for 40 minutes.

I made for family and friends, mostly people that have never had a stuffed pepper and everyone liked it.  I did slice peppers in half lenghtwise to make more and doubled the recipe. 3841580
Display Name:
haynesvillefarmer

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/239154.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made a few changes, hence the 4 stars. I didn't use tomato soup. I used tomato sauce(canned) with fresh herbs from my herb bed, greek oregano and sweet basil(1/4 cup each chopped), salt, black pepper, garlic powder and sugar. Browned the ground beef, drained, sauted onions, added chopped canned tomatos, one cup water, 1/2 cup cup long grain rice(long cooking), ground beef and simmer for 20-25 minutes, till rice is tender. Steamed peppers for 5 minutes(I don't think think this was necesary since I cooked stuffed peppers for 40 minutes at 350F). Stuffed peppers,split longways, poured sauce around and over, sprinkeled peppers with shredded colby/jack and baked for 40 minutes. Delicious.

text:
WE LOVED THEM, BUT I DID SOMETHING A LITTLE DIFFERENT.FIRST I USED MOZZARELLA FANCY SHREDDED CHEESE INTEAD OF REGULAR CHEESE AND THEN, INSTEAD OF THE TOMATO SAUCE I USED A LARGE CAN OF TRADITIONAL STYLE PASTA SAUCE. I USED ABOUT A HALF CAN OF WATER TO MAKE THE GRAVY LIKE TEXTURE. THEN AFTER THE MEAT AND RICE AND SPICES WERE COOKED I PUT ABOUT 1 CUP OF THE SAUCE AND CHEESE INTO THE MEAT MIXTURE. THEN LOADED UP THE PEPPERS AND TOPPED THEM WITH EXTRA MOZZARELLA CHEESE.I ALSO TOOK OUT THE STEM PART OF THE TOPS OF THE PEPPERS AND PLACED THEM BACK ON TOP THEN IN THE OVEN IT WENT. THEY WERE GREAT.I DID NOT HAVE A PROBLEM WITH THEM BEING BLAND AT ALL.EXCELLENT RECIPE WILL MAKE AGAIN.

text:
I had never made stuffed peppers before and I'm glad I did. They turned out really good. However, I only gave the recipe 4 stars because I cannot imagine that it would be good with out the addition of spices (I used 1 teaspoon cumin, 1/4 teaspoon garlic powder). The only other change I made was using cubbed cheddar instead of shredded and using soy burger instead of beef/turkey. My husband loved these, which shocked me because he tends to be pretty picky and these aren't exactly the normal comfort foods he usually enjoys. The leftovers the next day were absolutely amazing; the flavors were so much better!

These were pretty good!  I just added half a can of undiluted soup to the mix, then poured the rest over the top as stated.  It wasn't dry at all this way, as some others said!  I did not use a second can of soup at all.  Overall, these were very good, but not something I'll make super often -- I ended up cutting my pepper into bite size pieces and eating it like a casserole to make it less overwhelmingly "pepper-y." :)  But it is, after all, stuffed PEPPERS!  :)

region:

country:
None
text:
I made this for dinner tonight. After cutting the tops off of red and yellow peppers, I diced the extra pepper sections and added to the stuffing with Italian seasoning, minced shallots and garlic. I used a white/wild rice combo, and the water from the boiled peppers. *Regarding rice cook time, just follow the time noted on the rice.* I only used 1/2 a can of diced tomatoes (I don't like lots of mater chunks), and didn't have the tomato soup, so I didn't add it (I'm glad it wasn't a liquidy dish either). These tasted good, and could easily be spruced up for an Italian or Mexican dish. I served with spinach salad. Will be making again!

This was awesome!!  It also is a pretty good basic recipe that you could convert easily.  My suggestions:  I use Ground Turkey (more lean), garlic powder and seasoned salt in the turkey, 2 tsp Worcestershire and I chop up the tops of the green peppers and add them to the mixture.  I use tomato sauce instead of tomato soup and I put Monterey jack and Colby cheese for the inside and mozzarella on the top in the last few minutes before broiling ( to get a nice brown cheesy top).  Yum!  Even my kids like this one!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2008-08-31T09:08:38.237
helpfulCount:
0
userID:
3111349
Display Name:
goodcooker
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

1

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674147.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
In a hurry to get these made, I neglected to read the instructions. I used the listed ingredients (plus a few from other reviews) and came up with this: I cooked 1/2 lb. each of ground turkey and crumbled turkey Italian sausage with onion and garlic (3 cloves) in skillet. I added a can of diced tomatoes, one beef bouillon cube and 1/2 c. brown rice. I added 1 tsp. of thyme, oregano, and basil to the mix with 2 tsp. of Worcestershire. I let it simmer for about 10 min. then added 1 c. of shredded cheddar to it. I blancHed the halved peppers for 3 minutes and stuffed. They went into the pan (I added about 1/2 c. water in the bottom) and I topped them with 1c. marinara sauce and some extra cheese and baked 30 min. at 375. WONDERFUL!!!!! I did it wrong but they came out all right!

text:
This was great! My husband told me that he didn't like stuffed peppers (and isn't a leftover person) but after having this last night, he wants to finish the leftovers tonight! I also made a few changes... I cooked the rice for 5 minutes before adding it to the meat, and then added 1 cup of water, 2 beef bouillon cubes, 2 tsp of worcestershire instead of 1, a bay leaf, and finished it with 2 cups of cheddar cheese instead of 1. I also used half red peppers and half green peppers.

text:
The family loved this stuffed pepper recipe! It was wonderful! I try to rate the recipes as is, meaning I don't alter them ~ the FIRST time. If I feel the need after trying as is, I will do so. BUT, in this case, I had to alter two things...substitutions because I had no choice! First, I used monteray cheese instead of cheddar (it was all I had on hand. Well, that and mozzerella!). Second, I had no tomato soup, so I used a can of crushed tomatoes and added a bit of water and s&p. Pour that over the top. But I wouldn't have changed a thing from the original recipe! This is a keeper, for sure!

text:
This was very tasty! I made a few minor changes: I used ground turkey rather then beef, I boiled the peppers a bit longer because i like them softer, I used the basil seasoned diced canned tomatoes, added garlic/italian seasoning & a bit of red pepper spices, instead of using the full 2 cans of soup as topping i mixed half of one can in meat mix, upped the rice to 3/4 cup instant rice and added about 1/2 cup of corn. Now that i type it out it seems like a lot more changes but it really wasn't. All in all it was a very enjoyable easy meal.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I found the ratio of peppers to meat mixture to be way off.  I had enough meat to fill only 4 green peppers.  I made several changes and these turned out good.  Like others suggested I used 1 can petite diced tomatoes.  I used 3/4 cup cooked rice and I did not use water.  I used 1/2 cup beef broth.  I used approx. 2 tbls. of a homemade spaghetti sauce seasoning I have to season the meat also.  To fill the peppers I cut them long-ways to make "boats" to more even out the ratio of pepper to filling as some others suggested.  That worked very well!  I added extra cheese on top. Although the recipe was good, I decided I am just not a big cooked green pepper fan.  I will keep this recipe for the meat mixture.  As I made it it was fantastic on its own!  Now just have to find a use for it!!

I had instant rice on hand so I modified the recipe.  After cooking the peppers in water, I browned the meat, onion, and I used stewed tomatoes.  Since I omitted most of the salt in the recipe, I increased the worcestshire sauce to 2T.  Using instant rice allowed me to simmer the tomatoes covered for only five minutes.  (I didn't have to bake it in the oven.) Then, I added the cheese.  Very tasty.

text:
These were excellent.  I did not cook peppers in boiling water.  I filled them raw and they came out of the oven a little crunchy - really good.  I did add some italian seasoning to the beef mixture.  I also added 1/2 can tomato bisque soup to the beef mixture.  I used the other 1 1/2 cans to make the gravy that went over the peppers.  Instead of water I mixed the tomato soup with some milk.  Before filling green peppers I put 1/2 slice swiss cheese in bottom.  After baking 25-30 minutes I put a slice on top and baked til melted.   Another success for my husband.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674136.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I really wasn't a fan of this recipe at all. I thought it was bland and I made alterations too. The original recipe would have been too bland. My substitutions: I used ground turkey instead of beef, added 1 tsp of garlic powder, one small can of green chilis, substituted tomato soup for spicy ranchero tomato soup by campbells, substituted pepper jack cheese for cheddar and added about 8 drops of hot sauce. I precooked the rice to avoid undercooking. Also, I used only 5 bell peppers because I would have run out of filling with six.

I don't think I'll make this recipe again. I just wasn't impressed.

I cooked rice before adding to filling because have had problems with rice not being completely done in past stuffed pepper recipes.

country:
None
text:
These were much better than the recipe I have been using.  I would not change any proportions (rice or sauce).  Here are a few tips for saving time.  I used a can of diced tomatoes and frozen chopped onions. I also used 4 big red peppers, cut then in half length-wise, put them in my baking dish with about 1/2 cup water, covered with foil and steamed them in the oven for about 10-15 minutes while I was making the filling.  Saves a dish, and more intense flavor.  I might add some red pepper flakes next time.
